story: NewsCouple may have to sell home because of little-known pension ruleIf you used the old stamp system to make national insurance contributions you may need to check they are on a bookShareCommentsByGrace Witherden:,  AUG NewsBarry  Beryl Pettett at their house "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA little-known pension rule has left one couple wondering how they will survive after being told they will only receive half the pension amount they were expecting. Barry Pettett spent decades collecting national insurance stamps but he has now been told by HMRC that some of the stamps will not be accepted because they are not in a book. The -year-old from Shoreham-by-Sea, West Sussex, will now only receive £ a week state pension - and the house he shares with his we Beryl may have to be sold. This is because the self-employed builder used the old stamp system to make his national insurance contributions. Until April , Class  and  national insurance contributions were made by buying special adhesive stamps from the Post Office and affixing them to official national insurance cards. But this legislation was abolished in .    He told the: “How are we going to survive  We’ve got a small amount of savings but they won’t last long. It seems a terrible pensions injustice. “My we and I have lived in this road for  years and we bought our stamps and now they say they can’t accept them. We love this house. story: AdvertorialWhy incredible new dog charity - the first of its kind in UK - could be set for huge cash prizeThe Brainy Dogs scheme is a finalist in the th Birthday National Lottery AwardsShareByAlex LloydDave Masters:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG AdvertorialBrainy Dogs is run by the charity Headway Suffolk"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRESCUE dogs are being trained by vulnerable adults and teens to become canine companions for people with brain injuries. The Brainy Dogs scheme has created more than  le-changing new friendships to date, while giving offenders the chance to learn new skills. Now the National Lottery-funded project, the only one of its kind in the UK, is a finalist in the th Birthday National Lottery Awards, where you can help choose the winners. Brainy Dogs, which is run by the charity Headway Suffolk, is expanding to include one-to-one pet therapy sessions for clients who are not suitable for a companion dog and care home visits.  It is also offering people on probation, veterans, those with mental health problems and children excluded from school opportunities to train the animals. Headway Suffolk chief executive Helen Fairweather says: “Companion dogs can make a real dference to someone who is living with a neurological condition. “Their disabilities can often be hidden and may leave them with a personality change or dficulties that mean they lose friends and their families struggle to support them. “A dog can fill this void and provide help, comfort and confidence as they attempt to navigate le.” The charity boss came up with the unique scheme after reading a book about an assistance dog who aided the recovery of a brain-injured man and then watching a programme about prisoners in Australia training dogs. She realised that many of the people Headway works with could benefit from a similar furry friend. Many are not eligible to receive a dog from other charitable organisations as they are not regarded as having adequate need. Helen teamed up with Blue Cross Felixstowe and HMP Hollesley Bay in Suffolk for a one-year pilot in  and the concept has gone from strength to strength, receiving a £, grant from the National Lottery last year to expand. Brainy Dogs Coordinator Sophie Wellum-Mayes says training is inidual to each dog and client, taking around eight weeks.  Volunteer trainers gain work experience, le skills and improved confidence, along with improving the futures of the dogs and their new owners. She says: “The dogs calm clients in a way humans cannot. story: NewsOur baby could have been saved with a simple test - instead we watched her dieWARNING - UPSETTING CONTENT: Lyndsey Smitherman didnt get to hold her baby girl Sophie until she had died of Parvovirus B, also known as slapped cheek syndromeShareByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsSophie Carly Hope in intensive care - this was the first time her parents saw her properly "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving mum has described the heartbreaking two days she spent with her baby girl before she watched her die. Sophie Carly Hope Smitherman was born at .pm on December , . Her parents Lyndsey and Sam Smitherman heard her cry twice before she was rushed out of the room and taken to intensive care where she lived for less than  hours. The first time Lyndsey was able to hold her little girl was after she had died. She said it felt like apossomeone had torn her heart in halfapos. Sophieaposs mum and dad had just watched doctors desperately perform CPR on their tiny daughter but eventually there was nothing more that could be done. She had struggled to breathe immediately after birth and her platelets had not formed properly meaning she had been bleeding. She had a total of  blood transfusions in the  hours she was alive, her mum said. Her siblings Jack-James, six, Annabelle-Violet, five, and Meadow, four, tragically never got to meet their baby sister.    Lyndsey turned  on Motheraposs Day this year, but she said it killed me inside. The mum-of-four told how results from an autopsy two months after Sophieaposs death on .pm on the December , , revealed she had died of Parvovirus B. Parvovirus B is a virus that commonly infects children and is not routinely tested for during pregnancy. Lyndsey claims she was told by doctors thatshe had been tested for it during pregnancy, her baby could have been saved with a blood transfusion while still in the womb. The mum is now bravely sharing her story to raise awareness of the virus, in the hope that other pregnant women will become aware of it and consider requesting a test. Lyndsey says she does not want anyone  to suffer like they have had to.    Speaking to Mirror, Lyndsey, from Kent, described the heartbreaking moment her baby girl passed away as doctors performed CPR. She said: We kept on saying aposyou can make it, you can do it Sophie.apos I sort of zoned out and felt like it was not me in the room. They said aposwe are doing everything we can for herapos and carried on for a while longer. But then they came over and said aposwe have got to stopapos. It was like someone tore my heart in half and I wanted to collapse to the floor because I was in so much pain.  But I couldnapost collapse to the floor because no one would have been able to pick me up because of the pain. As soon as she passed away they said we could hold her. Within seconds I had her in my arms and it was the first time I held her. It was amazing to be able to feel her but hard knowing that she was not actually there.    The school supervisor added: The Parvovirus B had got to her so much it was shutting everything down. The virus was in her heart, so the whole body went into shut down. I wish I had been tested for it because then I would still have her here. Lyndsey and husband Sam, , found out in May last year they were expecting another baby. The mum said it was just like any of her other pregnancies, she was sailing through it, going to her scans, and everything seemed fine. But on Sunday December  when Lyndsey went to bed things werenapost quite right. There was not a lot of movement, she described. All my girls, when Iaposve been pregnant, have kicked me to pieces. Sophie would come up between me and Sam when he used to lie on my belly, but that evening she didnapost do it.  When Lyndsey woke up the following morning she said things had not got any better as she tried to get her moving. She phoned the hospital and explained how she felt reduced movement and was advised to go in to be checked out and monitored. At that point she was nearing the  week mark. When she went into hospital for tests, Lyndsey said medics told her aposwe need to get her out as soon asapos. Theyaposd picked up her heart rate was not great and it was like she was sleepy inside, Lyndsey said. They broke my waters to try and get everything started and my contractions began pretty quickly. But doctors could see she was not getting her breath back quickly enough so they suggested an emergency c-section. We wanted to be safe so we went for it. Lyndsey said doctors were reassuring about the cesarean and she and Sam felt quite relaxed as the procedure for Jack-Jamesapos birth had been OK. Sophie was born at .pm on December , , but she was immediately whisked away by medical staff. As soon as she was born, we heard her cry twice and then she was taken away from us to help her to breathe, Lyndsey told. Just as they said to Sam aposdo you want to come over and see her,apos they rushed her out of the room and said she needed to get a bit of help. We didnapost get told anything until we went into the recovery room.  Lyndsey said as it approached midnight a doctor came to show them a picture of their daughter and explained she was in intensive care having trouble with her lungs and was jaundiced. Other people were coming in the room with their babies, but I didnapost have my baby Lyndsey said, explaining she and Sam still hadnapost met their precious daughter properly in person. In the picture she had looked perfect, she was still our daughter. But it was heartbreaking not being able to see her. It was about .am on December  by the time they were allowed to see her. Before they took her, they brought her to us but it was only for five minutes, then they rushed her out, Lyndsey said. I wanted it to last longer, she said, but her baby needed a blood transfusion. We didnapost even get to touch her as she was in an incubator. The parents were warned Sophie was not forming her platelets which was causing her to bleed. We were told sheaposd need to be transferred to another hospital but I couldnapost go with her and had to wait until .am until the ambulance took me, Lyndsey said. Sam had to drive as they wouldnapost let him in the ambulance. When they got to the second hospital, little Sophie was having further scans. It was .am when they got to see her again. She was in her little incubator and had wires coming out everywhere, Lyndsey said. She had lots of dferent machines around her and a blue light on her for jaundice. Her skin was really shiny and she was very bloated because she was being pumped with dferent things. She couldnapost breath, she was having blood transfusions every hour. I loved the fact I was able to be there with her, but at the same time I was thinking aposshe has so much going onapos.  Lyndsey still tried so stay positive, and believed her daughter would be fine and that she was in the best place. I just wanted to spend all the time with her, she told. They allowed us to sit there and touch her. We were able to stick our hand through the holeand touch her hand. But after a little while of holding her, her stats dropped and we had to move. We werenapost allowed to touch our own daughter. Doctors were constantly at her side. At around .pm, Sophie had a terrying setback as she suffered a cardiac arrest. The parents were not present at the time and were told by doctors what had happened after they had aposbrought her backapos. They warned that aposthings werenapost brilliantapos. I was shocked and thought aposwhatanything had happened to her,apos Lyndsey told. But after they said they brought her back I felt positive she would be OK and she would pull through. I thoughtsheaposd got through that, she will get through this, little fighter.  Lyndseyaposs parents had brought the other kids to the hospital after school, but they were not allowed to see their new sister as she was too ill. Late that night, Lyndsey and Sam were askedthey had thought about christening their daughter. Sam asked, aposdoes that mean she is not going to pull through,apos but they wouldnapost answer that question, Lyndsey said. I kept thinking aposshe is my little girl, she will make it throughapos. Sophie was christened at am on December  with a priest coming into the hospital for the ceremony. By .am they were taken aside by a doctor who explained aposthings werenapost looking greatapos. He said only half of her heart was doing the work, Lyndsey said. He said aposshe may not make itapos andshe did things wouldnapost be brilliant for her. That made us feel really sick. We asked my parents to get the kids out of school early so they could come and see her before anything happened. The kids didnapost get to meet her at all. At . Lyndsey and Sam were back in ICU with their daughter but had to witness doctors performing CPR on her, at barely two days old. It was hard, very hard, it made me feel really, really low, Lyndsey said. She added: My parents had just arrived with the other kids, they were waiting outside the door when she passed away. Sam was there with me the whole time, he never left my side. All we left the hospital with was a memory box with a few things of hers - her little hat that held the tubes in place, little sunglasses to cover her eyes from the blue light. Lyndsey said two months later, following an autopsy, they found out their daughter had died of Parvovirus B, also known as aposslapped cheekapos. The NHS says:Parvovirus B is a virus that commonly infects children. It is usually transmitted by coughing and sneezing and hand washing is important in helping to prevent spread. For most healthy people, Parvovirus B causes a mild, self-limiting illness which is followed by le-long immunity. Pregnant women are not routinely screened for past Parvovirus B infection as there is no vaccine or preventative treatment available. The exact number of Parvovirus B infections in the UK is not known as the virus does not always show symptoms, and the diagnosis can only be confirmed by blood test. In women who are not immune, infection in the first  weeks of pregnancy can lead to serious problems for your baby before it is born.This would usually happen three to five weeks after the onset of maternal infection, but can be later. The greatest period of risk to the baby is between four to  weeks. Infection during this time can sometimes lead to serious complications such as fetal anaemia and sometimes fetal loss .There is a five – ten per cent risk of fetal losswomen develop this infection in the second trimester. Infection in the first month of pregnancy is not thought to carry any risk. Most babies will not be infected or affected by the virus. For more information, click here.

story: NewsSuicidal student jumped off building after crisis team told her sound, you can goSophie Sutton, who survived the fall from the top of University Hospital Aintrees car park, in Liverpool, said medics told her sound you can go despite her desperate warnings about her mental healthShareByJonathan HumphriesPippa Allen-Kinross:,  AUG NewsSophie feels like she wasnt taken seriously by hospital staff "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA student tried to leap to her death from a hospital car park after being discharged in the middle of the night by mental health workers she claims she had warned she was suicidal. Sophie Sutton, , was admitted to University Hospital Aintree in Liverpool on May  last year after taking an overdose, but says she was told to go home by medics despite her warnings that she wanted to jump.The former Liverpool John Moores University Student was left in agonising pain and needing surgery after shattering both her legs in the leap from the top of the multi-storey car park.She has been diagnosed with Emotional Unstable Personality Disorder and depression.    Sophie, from West Derby, told the Liverpool Echo that she had been struggling with low-mood, anxiety and suicidal thoughts. She said the jump was a genuine attempt to end her le but she did not feel that the mental health team took her seriously, despite a previous attempt to jump from the same car park. My heart was racing and I felt determined. I was scared at the same time. As I let go I felt instant regret and wanted to go back, but obviously couldnapost, she said. Sophie said she was taken to Aintree Hospital on May  by a relative after taking an overdose, and was checked over before being seen by the mental health team just after midnight.She said: There were two members of the crisis team I saw.We went to a room in AE majors and they asked me why I took the overdose, but at the time I was fixated on what I was doing to do [jump] but I was scared at the same time, so I told them I wanted to jump. They didnapost know how to respond. I donapost think they believed my intentions were real.   After I said I couldnapost get home and had no money, one member said apossound, you can go, find something to do for a few hours or you can walk homeapos so I felt judged and not taken seriously.Then I picked myself up and ran out. Sophieaposs case was one of a series of troubling incidents identied in a review into problems at Mersey Care NHS Foundation Trust, which runs the cityaposs mental health services.The thematic review action plan said some mental health practitioners at the trust, particularly those in hospital settings, were working with gaps in their knowledge.The report mentioned another woman who had thrown herself from the building after being admitted following an overdose. Since itaposs publication, a man in his s fell from the second floor after being sectioned.Sophie, who hopes to work as a mental health nurse, said she would have been seen as high risk after a similar suicide attempt around three months before the fall, when she took an overdose while an inpatient at Clock View Hospital in Walton. She was also taken to Aintree on that occasion and managed to make her way to the top floor of the car park building, but was stopped from jumping by police officers.Despite the warning signs, Sophie said she felt as though the crisis team did not take her intentions seriously, which only strengthened her intention to jump.She said: It was adrenaline at first but then I just got this huge, horrible pain in both legs, and I couldnapost feel my feet. I went back to Aintree in an ambulance and they gave me gas and air and ketamine. Sophie says the tibia and fibula in both legs were broken, and to make matters worse she developed a pulmonary embolism - a blood clot which travelled to her lung.She had surgery to replace metal rods in her legs and remained in hospital for two weeks, before spending another two weeks in a rehabilitation centre.

laterInvalid Email A radiation explosion in Russia that killed at least five people happened during a test of the nuclear engine of a deadly cruise missile nicknamed the aposFlying Chernobylapos, a leading Moscow journalist has claimed. The existence of the lethal weapon, which allegedly has an unlimited range, was revealed during a speech to senators last year by Russian president Vladimir Putin .Last weekaposs incident near Severodvink led to a radiation aposspikeapos, according to civilian authorities, but Moscow has faced criticism for not releasing a full explanation of exactly what caused the blast. Respected analyst Yulia Latynina has claimed the weapon that exploded was an ultra-modern missile called the Burevestnik.    Putin described it as having an unlimited range and a nuclear engine, which fits the sparse information released in the wake of the incident. Russian officials have not named the precise missile involved. It is highly likely that this is the one that exploded, Latynina, a respected columnist, author and radio host, wrote in investigative newspaper Novaya Gazeta. She dubbed the missile a small flying Chernobyl. If it was the Burevestnik, then the inner parts of its nuclear reactor - or, most likely, the liquid flowing there - ended up outside, she wrote.    This was just like the inner parts of the Chernobyl reactor which were thrown around the stationaposs territory by the explosion. US arms control expert Jeffrey Lewis has also suggested the blast could be related to the Burevestnik tests. Russiaaposs atomic agency Rosatom has revealed that a rocket engine test was underway and the accident involved isotope power sources. Separately, it has emerged that at least two corpses of top secret nuclear workers were blown into the sea by the force of the blast in the waters of the Nenoksa missile testing range. Three more bodies were recovered and will be buried on Monday. It is believed six injured scientists were moved to Moscow in ambulances with radiation protection. Latynina wrote: A flying nuclear reactor, evenyou isolate its active zone from the working body by the liquid zone, remains a small flying Chernobyl. Putin claimed last year that tests with the Burevestnik were successful, but this has been questioned by Western experts. Sources have said that only two tests out of  were partially successful by the start of this year. Last year, a CNBC report, citing US intelligence, claimed Russia was seeking to recover a nuclear-powered Burevestnik test missile that had crash landed in the Barents Sea, north of Norway and Russia. Reports suggest the new Russian weaponry threatens nuclear contamination.

title: dundees game of two halves leaves mcpake with decisions to make for ayr
story: Dundee welcome Ayr United to Dens Park this weekend looking for victory after kicking off the Championship campaign with a draw at Dunfermline.Saturday will be the Dark Blues fans’ first chance to get use out of their season tickets but what kind of Dundee side are they likely to see run out in the first home league match of the season Manager James McPake is the first to admit the first-half performance at East End Park was well below expectations at the club.With that in mind it’s highly unlikely he’ll choose the same unchanged side for the third match in a row.Half-time subs Declan McDaid and Josh Todd impressed from the bench on Friday night as Dundee came from two goals behind to draw - and will come into the manager’s thinking this weekend.McPake said: “I’ve watched it back and we weren’t good enough in the first half. We know that as a team.“But you ask for a reaction and you ask for character – that was there in abundance in the second half.“I thought the two boys, McDaid and Todd, coming on did really well and we looked more of a threat.“Looking back at the game now it was a game of two halves — a cliche I know — but it probably ended up a fair result.“Near the end I thought we might nick it, too.“Both McDaid and Todd have been in the mix. I like both of them, and Jamie Ness is back in the mix now, too.“It’s healthy we have him back and healthy we have those two pushing for places. That adds to the squad.”So, what are the possibilities for the Dens gaffer against Ian McCall’s Honest Men Despite an error for the second goal at Dunfermline, Jack Hamilton is the undisputed No  goalie at the club and will almost certainly retain his spot ahead of second-choice Calum Ferrie.After seeing the three-man backline perform well in a commanding performance against Inverness in the Betfred Cup the match previous, it’s clear the same line-up didn’t work at Dunfermline.Every game is dferent but should McPake switch to a back four, that’ll obviously see one centre-half drop out.The knock picked up by skipper Josh Meekings and his injury history make him favourite to miss out.Andrew Davies is nowhere near match fitness so that leaves Jordon Forster and Jordan McGhee as central defenders for this one.At full-back, Jordan Marshall did OK and will likely continue, as will Cammy Kerr on the right, though he didn’t have his best night at East End Park.A shake-up in defence would bring another midfielder into play and with McDaid, Todd and Ness all banging on the door for a starting spot, McPake has decisions to make. Young Finn Robertson has been excellent so far this campaign but his youthfulness may see him replaced by the more experienced Ness for this one.Paul McGowan and Shaun Byrne are key players but,Dundee go to a -- that’s likely to see one miss out – or McGowan moved further upfield.On the wings, McDaid and Todd may have done enough to earn their starting spurs.Danny Johnson’s three goals in two matches make him almost certain to start. Less certain is Andrew Nelson’s place after he was replaced at half-time on Friday, however.Injury and illness have hampered Craig Curran lately, though he is expected to be fit for Saturday.McGowan in behind Johnson could be McPake’s pick for this big early-season clash.

title: dundee united coach mcculloch wants to keep momentum going against partick
story: Assistant boss Lee McCulloch wants to see Dundee United gain some momentum by recording their second Championship win inside a week at Partick Thistle tonight.However, to do so, they’ll first have to snuff out the threat of a man he knows very well in veteran striker Kenny Miller.The pair worked on opposite sides of Tannadice Street in the final months of last season while Miller was at Dundee but, for years before that, they were team-mates at Rangers.From that time together, Lee knows, even at , the former Scotland striker is a force to be reckoned with.“Kenny is a threat. I played with him for years and years, and I know how good a player he was then. He’s still got that burst of pace, he’s still got the movement, the mentality and he is a leader on the pitch,” he said.“It’s going to be dficult to keep him quiet but we’ve got ways and means to do that. I think his attitude has been spot-on all through his career. I think he’s maybe changed his game a wee bit since he’s got older but he’s still very effective. He’s one of a number of danger men they have.”This week has seen talk of financial crisis at Thistle, who cancelled their team bus for last weekend’s opener at Alloa.They’ve also seen lottery winner Colin Weir withdraw his seven-figure backing.Whatever the repercussions, Lee knows, with the likes of Miller in their dressing-room, come the kick-off tomorrow, the Jags players will only be concentrating trying to get three points.“I think that’s the mentality their players will need to show. I don’t know what’s going on there, we just need to concentrate on ourselves, get ourselves ready,” he said.United, meanwhile, are relaxed over their young talent being tracked by a string of clubs down south.Although they declined to comment on the matter, there has been contact from Crystal Palace who were willing to pay £, for Scott Banks.That was never close to their valuation and, right now, there is no need to sell any player.The likes of Louis Appere and Logan Chalmers have also been watched in recent weeks but they are very much seen as part of the future plans at Tannadice.

title: aberdeen lose 1 0 to st mirren in premiership
story: Aberdeen will go into Thursday#s Europa League third qualying roundleg against Rijeka on the back of a Premiership loss to St Mirren.After their - defeat in Croatia, the Reds were looking to get back to winning ways, but Ilkay Durmus# early goal in Paisley denied them.Derek McInnes’ team never really got their attack going and were found to be vulnerable on the break in damp conditions.The rampant optimism of a week ago, after they’d beaten Georgians Chikhura Sachkhere and then Hearts at Pittodrie, has been dimmed, and they’ll need to improve across the board to have any chance of overturning the Croatian Cup winners’ - first leg lead and keep their hopes of the Euro group stage alive.McInnes made four changes from the team which lost - to Rijeka.Shay Logan, who handed Rijeka a penalty by pulling back Luka Capan, was dropped for new Bristol City loanee Zak Vyner, who made his first appearance.With one eye on Thursday’s , McInnes freshened up the attack with Scott Wright, Connor McLennan and league debutant Curtis Main in for Jon Gallagher, Niall McGinn and Sam Cosgrove – although there were questions marks as to whether Cosgrove’s absence was due to muscle tightness.St Mirren had the first chance to threaten on  minutes from a free-kick after Greg Leigh  bundled Paul McGinn to the deck on the right of the box.Durmus’ initial left-footed effort hit Funso Ojo in the wall, before Tony Andreu’s tame effort from  yards was caught easily by Joe Lewis.However, the home side opened the scoring on  minutes.Greg Leigh got caught out of position after a poor clearing header, with McGinn setting Kyle Magennis free down the right.He squared to the Durmus, who broke into the area and finished into the bottom right corner.It could’ve been two on  minutes. Calum Waters cross from the left headed over by Durmus.Main blazed a shot over from outside the area with  minutes played, having shrugged Gary Mackenzie off in the visitors’ first effort.The Dons interchanging midfield four of Wright, Ryan Hedges, Lewis Ferguson and McLennan wasn’t quite clicking for all their energy, with the man in possession being crowded out.Up the other end, big striker Jon Obika looked a real handful, with his pace, strength and aggression occupying Andy Considine and Scott McKenna.However, Hedges did find space to fire into Vaclav Hladky’s hands from  yards on  minutes, before Ferguson shot miles wide with a free-kick from  yards.Despite building a bit of pressure towards the end of the period, no more real chances materialised.Conversely, an  Andreu free-kick and Durmus overhead kick could’ve extended Saints’ lead, but were both caught by Lewis.Soon after play restarted, Main turned well with the ball and almost found the top left corner from range.On  minutes, Vyner got forward and delivered a pinpoint cross on to Ferguson’s head, and Hladky tipped over the bar.Three minutes later, the keeper threw himself on a deflected McLennan strike. However, he appeared to lt his hands from the ball, which Main stole and rolled into the net.Referee Steven McLean didn’t allow the equaliser – which would’ve been contentious – to stand.But it was a decent spell for Aberdeen, with Hladky punching a whipped Hedges free-kick clear soon after, before Sean McLoughlin looked to handle another of the attacker’s deliveries into the middle.Vyner was booked for protesting too vocerously for a penalty.Gaffer McInnes sent the rested Niall McGinn and Jon Gallagher on for McLennan and Wright in an attempt to force the issues for the Reds.But, on  minutes, St Mirren could’ve scored again, but Andreu somehow flicked Paul McGinn’s cross past the post.Ryan Flynn then went close with  minutes to go, ghosting inside, but shooting straight at Considine as he tried to find the inside of the front post.Kyle McAllister was next to try for the home side, and his long-range effort narrowly missed the top left corner.James Wilson was sent on for the Dons as they threw everything at the quick-countering Buddies to try and level it.The big chance of a frantic finish fell to substitute McGinn, from Considine’s cross, but he struck the outside of the post on the angle at the death.

title: aberdeen man climbs 50 munros in 150 days to raise cash for charlie house
story: An Aberdeen man who challenged himself to climb  Munros in only  days has completed his goal.Bruce Russell, director at recruitment business Right People, is a keen hillwalker and often tackles around  to  Munros a year.Alongside his we Clare for many of the treks, he took on the gruelling task – raising more than £, for children’s charity Charlie House in the process.Charlie House supports children and young people with complex disabilities and or le-limiting conditions.He also often took along its mascot Charlie Dog for the journey.Bruce said: “This was a much bigger challenge than I expected but the thought of those who would benefit kept me going.“It’s such a worthwhile cause, I’m delighted I could contribute. After climbing Munros right across Scotland, it was nice to finish up relatively close to home.“I was delighted to complete the challenge at the weekend and would like to thank everyone who has supported me.”Since beginning the challenge at the end of March, he has walked  miles – a total ascent of ,m. This is the equivalent of climbing Mount Everest – which is ,m – more than three times.Kirsty Walker, fundraising co-ordinator at Charlie House, said: “What a fantastic achievement. We can’t thank Bruce enough for what he has done.“He’s basically devoted much of his free time over the past four months to support our appeal to raise £ million to build a specialist support centre. His contribution will make a huge dference to the lives of many children and young people in the north-east of Scotland.”The money raised will go towards Charlie House’s Big Build Appeal, which was launched in November last year.It aims to raise £m to build a new specialist support centre set in four acres of ground at Woodend Hospital.A range of dferent facilities will be on offer to benefit youngsters and their families.These include a spa pool, teen den, Star room for end-of-le care and bereavement, sensory gardens, and more. Similar facilities can currently only be accessed in Kinross, more than  miles away, which aren’t available for many north-east families.There will also be dedicated office facilities for Charlie House employees.Donations to Bruce’s fundraiser can still be made online at www.justgiving  fundraising bruce-russell

title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

story: Barabel McKayUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsLast year we were studying the Argyll and Bute Health and Social Care Partnership#Transforming Together#   document, which presented a vision of combining our will and skills to create a healthy future for the citizens of Argyll.The promises in that did not translate into reality.Now, a  beautully constructed and presented Living Well document is available. title: northern jolly for loch fyne anglers
story: Nikki ThompsonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Loch Fyne Sea Angling Club couldn’t have asked for better weather for its annual soirée to the fertile fishing grounds of Stornoway.The crossing from Ullapool was as smooth as you like and a sure sign we were in for a good couple of days. Day one saw us head out from Carloway aboard the SYSAC II under the watchful eye of skippper Robbie Bell who knows these waters like the back of his hand.The day kicked off with a bait hunt in the East Loch but the mackerel were pretty scarce, it took an hour or so to fill the baskets before steaming out to the two-mile mark in search of spurdogs. By then there was a fair wee wind picking up and it was a tad rough to say the least, with the heavy swell claiming a few breakfasts along the way.All that was soon forgotten as the battle commenced with the mighty spurs. The action started on the first drop with some thumpers coming aboard, single and double shots causing mayhem thrashing about the deck and we lost count of the number of rigs sliced through on the way up. But that’s what we came for, not everyone’s choice but great sport all the same.In between the madness we picked away at the haddock, whiting, grey and red gurnard, ling and pollack, until we had our quota and decided to seek the smoother waters of East Loch Roag for some flattie bashing on the soft ground. It was good to get into the calm and fish the light gear, picking away for dabs and plaice. There was plenty around, nothing huge but a steady flow coming aboard taking us to the end of the day with a good mixed bag of species.Day two set off in brilliant sunshine and not a breath of wind, it was almost tropical conditions. We quickly got our supply of fresh bait in West Loch Roag and set off for the rough ground in search of a few more species, but there was little or no drt so we took a turn into Clf Bay and settled in for a day on the rays. It was brilliant fun, everyone got their fair share with loads of thornback rays and a few spotted rays coming aboard, plenty of dabs, plaice, dogfish and a bonus lb oz turbot to add to the tally. It was a great opportunity to brush up on some of fishing techniques that don’t get practised much at home.We decided to hit the hard ground on the way back to the harbour. It was quite slow, maybe a wee bit early yet, but it produced more haddock, a lovely lb cuckoo wrasse and pollack bringing our two day adventure to an end. All in all another excellent club trip.This year we picked up  species,  counting fish and a few personal bests. Add to that, great company, loads of banter, a good skipper who makes a mean cup o’ tea and you have the ideal ingredients for another memorable few days away on Lewis. We’ll be back next year for sure.Results: Nikki Thompson  points, Robert MacBrayne , Nick Friel , Jim Smith , Gary Sinclair , Steven MacBrayne .

title: mach1 scottish tarmack rally championship report
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowWith  starters and  Cobble shop STRC registered the championship tables were always going to change on this mid-season two day event.Sunshine was forecast for the Machrihanish Airbase Community Companycourse and that’s what was delivered. Some crews were hoping for rain but this year it wasn’t to be. Last year’s winner Bruce Edwards in the Darrian T GTR was favourite and since Bruce had not driven the car competitively since Mach   we all thought he would be a bit rusty.Bruce led from the start and set some impressive times throughout the two days but on the last stage he threw it all away and rolled the car as he clipped a large lorry tyre a mile from the finish line, unable to right the car and with the stage blocked the clerk of the course decided on the grounds of safety to cancel the final stage. This allowed Alistair Inglis in the lotus Exige and a previous Mach  winner to clinch the top spot.Class  had  STRC registered this year and new to class  was Tom Blackwood in the gorgeous yellow and Black Fiesta R+. Tom#s first event driving in anger and showed that with some tweaks here and there with suspension settings it’s a great car to drive. How well the car drives notwithstanding, there was a slight moment coming out of one of the tight sections onto the main runway when Tom ran wide and clipped a boundary fence damaging the front bumper of the car but kept the fence intact. Tom finished third Overall and second in class .John Rintoul in another Fiesta R on the back of the recent win at Crail was on it all weekend but just couldn’t clinch the win this year, John finished second overall and took the class win.Alan Wallace in the distinctive green and white Mitsubishi Evo finished a very well deserved th overall and third in class. Harry Chalmers was a Mach  virgin and loved every mile of the venue. Harry commented at the end of the event they we had no problems at all on day one and the car ran faultlessly all day to give him a real confidence boost to push on harder and let him get used to some new parts on the car. Harry kept it neat all day and came away with rd overall after day one.Day two was very fast. Fastest he’s probably been in the car to date with these faster stages suiting faster cars Harry just had to push on brake late and keep it tidy and with that being said the team dropped to th overall due to some of the quicker cars retiring out.Harry said: #I couldn’t be happier for how this event turned out for the team and are all delighted with the result and how far they have come.#Harry also managed the full two days on the same Hankook Tyres Finishing th overall.Alan Stark in the stunning Red Mitsubishi Evo had decided he was playing the long game and would drive accordingly. The plan went well and they played about with tyres trying to make them last for the two days. On the second last stage on the Saturday the manold gasket started to blow and he lost a fair bit of power mid stage. The service crew managed to bolt it up again but the long stages were killing it and it usually faded about  rds in each time.On Sunday he decided to push on a bit and of course it bit him. The interior mirror fell off and he became aware there was a car coming up behind after a merge but wasn’t sure how close. He decided to do the next lollipop and then see where he was on the straight but in his enthusiasm got to him and he understeered into the bales bouncing off them, hitting his bonnet. He also noticed the brake pads were rattling more than usual and it turned out they had lost a pin. The team had to improvise with spare tyre borrowed from Allan Wallace which didn’t quite fit but they wired it in and it lasted.Class  had  STRC registered crews this year and top spot and current championship leader in class went to Colin Gemmell in the Mark  Escort. Colin had a trouble-free run on both days and managed to finish the event th overall just  seconds behind Tom Blackwood and second in class.Alistair Inglis winner of the  Mach  stages kept just ahead all weekend. Nothing could touch his car which stuck to the road like glue.Inglis said: #Overall victory and a class win  Can’t get any better.#Robert Marshall in the Mark  Escort was looking forward to some decent results but an issue on day one with the car losing all its water put an end to any real chances and on day two an engine mount broke putting an end to what Robert described as a perfect weekend.Ross Auld was a welcomethe Mark  Escort and also managed a couple of days assistance in setting up the venue. Ross had managed to set some decent times on Saturday but late in the day the alternator belt snapped and took with it the dry sump belt causing the engine to cease. Ross loaded up the car and headed home and by the Sunday evening he had the engine out the car ahead of its rebuild.Class  saw four STRC registered crews compete in Kintyre this year and top of the list was Greg Inglis in the Lotus Exige. Greg exited the last stage on the Saturday and noticed the rear brake calliper hanging off. A call was made to Montrose where a spare part was removed from a car and the handover was done half way between Montrose and Machrihanish. Greg finished a respectful fth overall and took the class win.Second in class and th overall was Michael Harbour in the Mark  Escort, on the back of electrical problems that saw the team fail to finish the last round at Crail the team have now got the car singing on the stages. Michael didn’t report any issues during the weekend and brought the car home in one piece.Michael Robertson isn’t having the best of luck this season as the Honda Civic Type R driver reported issues with the CV joint that led to driveshaft and df failure but as usual the team loved the event and will be back for sure.Class , with eight registered STRC in class  the battles were all tensely close. Taking top honours in the class was Kyle Adam a full two minutes ahead of nearest class  car of Des Campbell. Kyle also managed a top  overall clinching th spot and despite some overheating at one point the car ran faultlessly doing his championship hopes no harm.Lochgilphead local, Jamie Miller in the C R Max loves the track and had the luxury of booking indoor servicing. With navigator Ian McCulloch, his biggest problems were brake related but with some fluid changes and adjustments it was just all back to normal for the team finishing a well-deserved th overall and fourth in class.Kayleigh Strachan in the Citroen Saxo finished th in class on the event and th overall but managed to pick up  points and th in class in the STRC.Gary Coutts in the Fiesta commented after the final stage on the Sunday that on the second to last stage of day one he developed a few ‘minor’ issues. A change of driveshaft, ball joint, wheels and tyres seemed to cure the problem. With an early start on the Sunday morning the car was back on form. Loss of intercom on way to stage  and a half spin on stage  cost them a bit of time and after a few tweaks at service they were away again. The last stage of the day was cancelled resulting in a th overall and th in class.Alan Watt was again out in the green Saxo and finished th in class and st overall. A great result for the team with no damage or mechanical issues to report.Class  had four teams registered in the STRC this year at Mach  but only one managed to finish. Martin Farquhar in the  didn’t have any issues to report with the car and managed first in class in the STRC but second in class on the event and th overall.Event Overall and Class winners: st Overall Alistair Inglis Colin Inglis Lotus Exige ., nd Overall John Rintoul Ross Hynd Ford Fiesta R ., rd Overall Tom Blackwood Gordon Winning Ford Fiesta R+ ..Class  Martin Farquhar Aiden Henderson Peugeot  .Class  Kyle Adam Fiona Moir Ford Escort Mk .Class  Greg Inglis Steven Brown Lotus Exige .Class  Colin Gemmell Richard Crozier Ford Escort Mk .Class  John Rintoul Ross Hynd Ford Fiesta R .

title: 19th argyll scouts share their summer adventures

It would be fair to say the midges enjoyed a feast, chewing both young people and their guests with vigour. But they didn#t dampen the spirits of the Scouts who were presented with numerous awards including Bronze, Silver and Gold Chief Scout Awards.The highlight of the evening was the presentation to Martha Payne of her Diamond Chief Scout Award, the second highest award in Scouting. Martha has been an enthusiastic and active member of the th Argyll for more than seven years.After gaining her award she said: #I have loved my time in Scouting – it has provided me with so many opportunities and memories.#Shortly after receiving her Diamond Chief Scout Award, Martha and her sister Polly, jetted off to join , other Scouts from around the world at the th World Scout Jamboree in West Virginia. This event is held every four years in dferent countries. The objective is to promote peace and understanding and to develop leadership and le skills in those attending.While Martha and Polly were in the United States, seven members of the th Argyll travelled to the world’s oldest rainforest in northern Malaysia to take part in a community development project with members of the Orang Asli tribe.The project had been organised by the West Region of Scouting in Scotland supported by the Yayasan EMKAY foundation. This charity exists to improve the living standards of the people living in this remote and challenging area. In total the group comprised  leaders and  explorersand networkerscompleting four projects.The projects included renovating a classroom to allow the villagers to attract a primary school teacher , building a playpark , preparing fields for planting of fruit trees, herbs and vegetables, and building a table for the elders to meet and discuss village business.Working in the rainforest was challenging with very high levels of humidity and temperatures regularly touching C. The whole group had an amazing adventure with memories and friendships formed that will last a letime.Finally, two members of the th Argyll had their first outings as members of the Mid Argyll Pipe Band. Robert Tonerand Martha Moirtook part in the recent Ardrishaig Gala Day.David Smart, Scout leader, th Argyll said: #This has been an amazing summer. We are so proud of all our members who have grasped the opportunities that Scouting provides. Scouting for the th is all about having adventures, whether small ones or big ones.#Last year we ran two camps for our Beavers, our Cubs attended the Adventure Centre at Lochgoilhead and won the District Camping competition, our Scouts completed a number of weekend camps including the Snowdrop Challenge Hike, and our Explorers had their first taste of ice climbing. Next year is our th birthday and we are planning a whole host of activities and adventures to mark this milestone.#John McCartan, chairman of the group, said: #Scouting in Mid Argyll is as strong as it has ever been. The leadership team, guided by the young people, have developed a fantastic programme in all of the sections.#We are keen that as many young people in Argyll take up the opportunities that Scouting provides. We have a stand at the forthcoming Mid Argyll Show and would be delighted to discuss our plans.#If you are interested in finding out more about the th Argyll Lochgilphead Scouts, email thargyllscouts@gmail or call  .The group runs four sections – Beavers , Cubs , Scoutsand Explorers . There are spaces in all sections for boys and girls. The group is also keen to talk to adults about how they can help the group either as unormed leaders or as supporters.PIC:Martha Payne and Polly Payne at World Scout Jamboree. no_ascoutsCameron Garrett harvesting bamboo in the rainforest. no_ascoutsAnna Turner designing a Jungle Book mural in the renovated classroom. no_ascoutsAndrew Smart and Lorne Barrie building the playpark for youngsters in the village. no_ascoutsJames Urquhart drilling components for the play park. no_ascoutsAnne Smart, leader of the agricultural project. no_ascouts

title: the egg shed hatches in ardrishaig
story: Janet WestUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowArdrishaig’s brand new heritage and community hub, the Egg Shed, opened to the public on Friday August , and with music, entertainment and lots of sunshine, it was a cracking day out.The Egg Shed, which had historically been used as an egg grading station, has been revived from a disused building into a bespoke interpretation and community centre which tells the story of the Crinan Canal and the communities which lie on its banks.The building is now home to a living archive with stories, photos and memorabilia, much of it donated by the local community, just waiting to be discovered.In amongst the formalities of opening the £. million Egg Shed and marking the official twinning of the Crinan Canal with Sweden’s Dalslands Kanal attended by CEO Benny Ruus, there was plenty of time for some fun in the Ardrishaig sunshine. Ardrishaig Bothy was open and help was on hand to introduce youngsters to riding a bike, or brush up on their cycle control skills. There was also a unique opportunity to join the th Duke of Argyll on a walking tour of the Crinan Canal as he uncovered the Chronicles of Crinan, butthat was too energetic then there was the option of sitting back to be entertained.Mid Argyll Pipe Band took time off from competition to play to the crowds. They joined some local bands who made sure toes were tapping from early morning until the end of the day.Of course, the main event was the ribbon cutting to formally open the Egg Shed and let the crowd who had gathered in Pier Square get a first look at the much-anticipated new building. Scottish Canals Chief Executive Catherine Topley together with Chief Executive of Argyll and Bute Council Cleland Sneddon addressed the crowd before enlisting the help of some young local helpers to help cut the ribbon and allow the first guests to flood in.As well as learning more about ‘Britain’s most beautul shortcut’, and its souvenir shop, the Egg Shed hosts a multi-purpose community space, free for the local community to use, which has a multitude of uses. It currently hosts an exhibition of Crinan Canal paintings by artist Richard Demarko, who when asked how he would describe them said they were: ‘a love letter to the Crinan Canal.’Mid Argyll Councillor Dougie Philand attended the launch and said: #It was a very well organised event and well attended. It sends out the signal that not only Scottish Canals but other partners are interested and are now investing in Ardrishaig. Long may this continue in order to regenerate the village back to the splendour it once enjoyed.#Councillor Donnie Macmillan, who also attended said: #I had a wonderful day at the opening of The Egg Shed. I would like to congratulate everyone who helped to make it a professional and successful day. Everyone involved played their part in a professional manner.#I hope this is an important part of the regeneration of Mid Argyll and I will continue to give them all my support in my duties as a councillor.#The Egg Shed is the latest marker in the regeneration of Ardrishaig Harbour and has already been taken to the community’s heart. It will be eggciting to see what the future holds.

title: power-point-galashiels-sewage-plant
story: BOSSES at Scottish Water are so proud of their Gala waste treatment works that they want to tell the world.And they made a start last week by erecting signs around on the gates of the riverside plant as well as next to popular pathways.The bright blue signs highlight the energy savings generated at the pioneering site.As well as brief explanation on how the site uses a technique called Combined Heat and Power the signs also describe how the works are now one of Scottish waters most self-sufficient energy sites, generating enough power for  homes.Site operator Brian Reavely, who has worked at the Gala plant for the past  years told us: "Most people in Galashiels know this site is here and what it does, but not many know just how energy efficient it is."We wanted to do something to let people living here and visiting the area about how green this place ndash which provides a vital service to the town and surrounding area ndash is.ldquoI had made paper made signs reminding us of how self-sufficient the site is and put them in ious places such like our canteen and noticeboard. I thought it would be a good idea to let people in the area know about our achievements and it was decided a plaque highlighting how energy efficient we are was a good way to do this.ldquoMany people use the walkways around here and I hope they will be interested in learning about how green we are. It is a great achievement and makes me proud to work here.More than  of Scottish Waterrsquos water and wastewater treatment works are either self-sufficient or partly sufficient in their power requirements, leading to lower operating costs and a more sustainable business.Since the Galashiels site started using Combined Heat and Power four years ago the amount of energy it imports has dropped by two thirds.The Galashiels site treats sludge from most parts of the Borders including Eyemouth in the east to Newcastleton in the west.

title: thousands-littered-bottles-set-vanish-borders-thanks-20p-recycling-scheme
story: People in the Borders can wave goodbye to as many as , plastic bottles next year thanks to new Deposit Return scheme.Thousands of plastic bottles and cans could be kept out of the environment in the Scottish Borders due to a pioneering new lsquomoney backrsquo system that will encourage people to recycle more and litter less.Figures published by environmental body Zero Waste Scotland, revealed the scale of plastic bottle dumping in the Scottish Borders.And how it will be reduced by Scotlandrsquos forthcoming depositscheme.Every year, people in the Scottish Borders go through . million plastic bottles.And an estimated , of those plastic bottles are littered around the Borders each year.Under the new scheme, shoppers will pay a p deposit when buying drinks purchased in single-use plastic, glass bottles, and aluminium or steel cans.People will then get their money back when theytheir empty container for recycling.That p is hoped to give people an extra incentive to recycle their empty bottles and cans, and make people think twice about dropping them.With a p incentive not to throw away your empties, Zero Waste Scotland anticipates a  per cent reduction in litter for the materials mentioned.This would mean nearly , fewer plastic bottles dropped in Scottish Borders each year.With plastic bottles only one of the materials included in the scheme, the overall impact on litter is expected to be even higher.Jill Farrell, Chief Operating Officer, Zero Waste Scotland said: ldquoOur new figures reveal how Scotlandrsquos Deposit Return Scheme could visibly slash the number of littered plastic bottles in the Borders.ldquoWe all hate seeing empty bottles and cans littering our streets, green spaces and beaches.ldquoAnd the great thing about Scotlandrsquos Deposit Return Scheme is it will give people a p incentive to do the right thing with their empty bottles, take them back for recycling, rather than risk them ending up on our streets or in our rivers.ldquoLitter isnrsquot just an eyesore ndash it also pollutes our environment and seas.ldquoAnd for every bottle littered, more plastic must be created, generating more planet-damaging emissions.ldquoWhen you take back your empty bottles to be recycled, yoursquoll not just be getting your p back, yoursquoll be doing your bit in the fight against the climate emergency.All types of drinks in containers between  ml and  litres in size are included in the Deposit Return scheme.Across Scotland, wherever people can buy a drink in a container made from one of these materials, they will also be able toit to reclaim the deposit.Online retailers will also be included in the scheme, ensuring itrsquos accessible to people that are dependent on online delivery.The Scottish Government is expected to introduce legislation to enable the scheme later this year.For more information about Scotlandrsquos Deposit Return Scheme, visit www.deposit.scot

title: earl-39-s-rare-unseen-photographs-go-display
story: AN exhibition charting the photography of a former Earl is being developed at Thirlestane Castle.The new photography exhibition features works by the th Earl of Lauderdale which have never been on public display before.The exhibition will include some of the early bromoil printing techniques used by Frederick Colin Maitland at the turn of the last century, as well as pre-Photoshop examples of edited images and how these were achieved.As well as never before seen images, there will also be a selection of his more vernacular work to give audiences a taster of the th Earlrsquos broad range of photographic skills.Entitled lsquoTheoretical Sharpnessrsquo, the exhibition has been created by local photography artist Sam Cornwell.He was tasked with beginning the curation, study and preservation of the th Earlrsquos extensive archive that dates from the late th century.During his work he was fascinated by a series of images of clouds which the th Earl used as a library for the editing of his work.The title of the exhibition comes from one of many columns Maitland wrote for a national newspaper in the s.A phrase he coined that epitomises his work he considered that photographs in total sharpness were not artistic at all, and this is reflected in his award winning work.Edward Maitland-Carew said: ldquoI am so thrilled to be able to share my great, great grandfatherrsquos amazing work with a wider audience."The th Earl of Lauderdale was extremely talented and very much at the forefront of the photography world winning many awards for his work."Sam Cornwell has done a fantastic job at examining these unique pieces and preparing them for display.The exhibition will be open from am daily between Monday and Thursday, August  and  and is included in the normal admission ticket to the castle.

title: kalzie-takes-flutter-new-butterfly-house
