title: job-losses-empty-units-arcadia-group-pulls-galashiels
story: UP to  jobs could be lost in the next couple of months with the planned closure of two clothing stores in Galashiels.It is understood that the shutters will come down on both Burtons and Dorothy Perkins in October.Although nobody at the Arcadia Group headquarters would discuss or confirm the reports, staff have been notied and closing down posters were placed in the windows last week.As well as the loss of jobs, the store closures will add to the number of empty units on one of Galas main shopping streets.Councillor Euan Jardine told us: "I am extremely disappointed that these stores are closing."They have been an asset to Galashiels and the region for many years and I have written to Arcadia to vent my frustration and also ask about the future of the staff that are employed in store."Unfortunately, peoplersquos shopping habits are changing."The fact you can now in certain places get same day delivery from stores like Amazon, really shows how hard it is for retail stores to survive on the modern day high street."There are already close to a dozen empty shops on the main street leading up to the under-construction Tapestry Visitor Centre.Councillor Jardine hopes ongoing talks with retail groups will attract new businesses to Galashiels ahead of the grand opening.He added: "The council have been contacting national retail providers in an effort to occupy empty stores on Channel Street."They have faced a few stumbling blocks to retailers commitment to expansion which include ious political matters that dominate the headlines both in Scotland and Britain as a whole."However, with the Tapestry opening soon, the footfall in the area will increase and this is one of the main selling points we are using when trying to entice retailers."I also think discussions with the people responsible for letting these properties has to be explored."I would ask for any business to have faith in the town, which is going through a phase of regeneration and really emphasise the point that Galashiels is open for business and a great place for your business to succeed."Sir Philip Greens Arcadia Group announced in May that it was closing  stores across the UK with the loss of around  jobs.But only Glasgow and Aberdeen were the Scottish outlets to appear on the hit list.But further financial problems for the international retail group in June led to a rescue plan being unveiled to shareholders involving , job losses and shutting a further  stores.The Arcadia Group, whose brands also include Topshop, Miss Selfridge and Evans, have refused to discuss this latest tranch of closures.But chief executive Ian Grabiner was more talkative in May when announcing the initial job losses.He said: "Against a backdrop of challenging retail headwinds, changing consumer habits and ever-increasing online competition, we have seriously considered all possible strategic options tothe Group to a stable financial .ldquoThis has been a tough but necessary decision for the business."

title: galashiels-set-scottish-opera-39-s-highlights
story: GALASHIELS has been included in Scottish Operarsquos hugely popular Opera Highlights tour.From next month four singers and a pianist will travel theand breadth of the country to perform.And on Tuesday, October  they arrive at the Volunteer Hall.The setting for director Roxana Hainesrsquo production of Opera Highlights is a beautul garden party, and features a playlist of operatic classics and must-hear rarities, curated by Scottish Operarsquos Head of Music Derek Clark.Highlights include Delibesrsquo Flower Duet, Vaughan Williamsrsquo Blue Larkspur in a Garden and many more from the likes of Mozart, Lehaacuter and Scottish Opera Composer in Residence, Samuel Bordoli.Pianist Music Director Ian Shaw is joined by Scottish Opera emerging soprano Charlie Drummond mezzo-soprano Martha Jones tenor Alex Bevan and baritone Mark Nathan.Roxana Haines, who is directing Scottish Operarsquos Fox-tot! at Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer, said: "This years Opera Highlights cast cordially invite you to a party on your doorstep, set throughout luscious gardens and magical flora and fauna of Opera."The stage has been set, decorations unpacked and the guests have all arrived but, the only problem is, no one quite knows who or why were celebrating."As the evening progresses, the connections between our characters unravel through music from the likes of Handel, Donizetti and Mozart, and lighter pieces from Gilbert  Sullivan and Vaughan Williams as well as a new work by Samuel Bordoli."Prepare for charm, magic and love in all its operatic forms."The same show s in Spring , with a dferent cast: soprano Zoe Drummond mezzo-soprano Jade Moffat tenor Andrew Irwin and baritone Arthur Bruce, with Peebles included in next years dates.Scottish Operarsquos general director Alex Reedijk told us: "I am delighted that Scottish Opera will be touring what promises to be another sensational Opera Highlights to  venues across Scotland in the Autumn and Spring."This longstanding and much acclaimed commitment by the Company to presenting work across Scotland is part of what makes us Scottish Opera, and is welcomed by our far-flung audiences as a lovely operatic tonic!"Opera Highlights also serves to introduce young singers to our audiences, and greatly assists their development as artists alongside presenting the joys of opera and singing to our widely spread audience.rsquo"This Opera Highlights tour is supported by The Friends of Scottish Opera, JTH Charitable Trust and The Scottish Opera Endowment Trust.

title: earlston-welcomes-brand-new-burns-mozart-inspired-opera
story: BURNS night is back, and this time with an operatic twist.Touring this autumn is Amadeus  The Bard: th Century Cosmic Brothers, a brand-new show from Scottish Opera.Debuting at Earlston High School, Amadeus  The Bard celebrates the lives of two much-loved men, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Robert Burns.Through storytelling and song, Scottish Opera will honour the many and sometimes surprising similarities between them.Created and directed by Mary McCluskey the former Artistic Director of Scottish Youth Theatre, the show is sure to entertain.Opening night is in Earlston High School after which the production tours to schools in six other Scottish towns, as well as the National Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh.And the Scottish Opera Production Studios in Glasgow.Set in Poosie Nansiersquos Inn, a favourite haunt of Burns, the cast blend traditional folk songs with some of Mozartrsquos most popular work.From Tam OrsquoShanter and The Magic Flute, to A Red, Red Rose and The Marriage of Figaro, audiences are sure to enjoy the night in celebration of the beloved musical geniuses.Jane Davidson, Scottish Operarsquos Director of Outreach and Education said: ldquoAmadeus  The Bard affords us some fascinating glimpses into thelives of Robert Burns and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.ldquoBoth are cultural icons of the eighteenth century whose musical and literary lsquovoicesrsquo have inspired people through the generations down to the present day.Karen MacIver is the Music Director and pianist on this dramatic show, which features a talented cast including Arthur Bruce, The Robertson Trust Scottish Opera Emerging Artist .Alongside Arthur will be actor Andy Clark, soprano Stephanie Stanway and violinist Shannon Stevenson.They are joined by an ensemble of four singers from Scottish Opera Young Company: Cara Blaikie, Ross Fettes, James McIntyre and Erin Spence.Director Mary McCluskey said: ldquoIt is our intention for our merry band of talented performers, singers, actors and musicians to give you an insight into the work of Mozart and Burns.ldquoWe hope to entertain and inform you, in order that you will leave knowing more than you did when you came along to see the production, and that we will have whetted your appetite for the work of these two talented men.Jane added: ldquoThe warmest of welcomes is extended to everyone to join our dynamic young company of performers around the fireside in Poosie Nansiersquos hostelry for an hour of songs, ensembles, arias and poetry.The performance takes place in Earlston High School on Monday, September  at pm.For more information visit https:www.scottishopera.org.uk amadeus

title: combat-loneliness-chatty-cafe
story: HAWICK is being introduced to a new scheme to help battle loneliness in the community.Now, people who fancy a chat with someone new while enjoying a cuppa, can do so at Heart of Hawick.Introduced to the area by Live Borders, the Chatty Cafeacute scheme, is also spreading across the UK.There are now over  cafes taking part and anyone can join in.If yoursquore on your own, in a couple, or with a friend or child, look for the sign on the table, and take a seat.Alexandra Hoskyn, Founder of The Chatty Cafeacute scheme, said: ldquoThe scheme was created on a wet and windy day when I was in a supermarket cafeacute with my four-month-old son.ldquoHe wasnrsquot great company and I was fed up. I looked around the cafeacute and saw an elderly lady who looked just as down as me and, on another table, sat a young guy with additional needs and his support worker, both looking like they had run out of conversation.ldquoI started to think about the positive impact we could have had on each otherwe had sat together.ldquoI know from experience that when you are feeling lonely, a short conversation with another human can really brighten your day and I realised that you can be out of the house all day yet have no interaction with another person.And so, Alexandra came up with the idea of a Chatter  Natter table where customers can sitthey would like to talk to other customers.A lsquoChatter  Natterrsquo table is a space for people to talk whether it is for five minutes or longer.The scheme encourages simple interactions to combat loneliness: a chat may have a big impact on someonersquos day.Sophy Delavigne, Operations Manager at Heart of Hawick said: ldquoAs soon as we heard about the Chatty Cafeacute scheme, Heart of Hawick wanted to join.ldquoWe think itrsquos a fantastic idea and already have the support of our regular customers.ldquoAs a charity, every penny spent across Live Borders centres and venues is invested back into the community to help make lives healthier, happier and stronger, which this scheme definitely accomplishes.For further information visit: www.heartofhawick and thechattycafescheme blog

title: defending-champions-come-top-ettrick-sports
story: STAGED for the first time at Cossarshill, Saturdayrsquos annual Ettrick Sports event attracted good fields of competitors from the valley and beyond.Tommy Bryson successfully defended his menrsquos title to once again lt the Napier Cup, while Kirsty Skea repeated her  ladies section triumph by taking the Chrissy Thomson Trophy.Fraser Davidson and Jenner Davidson finished as runner-up in their respective sections.ADULTSNapier Cup, Tommy Bryson runner-up, Fraser Davidson.Chrissy Thomson Trophy, Kirsty Skea runner-up , Jenner Davidson.John Dodds Trophy , Tommy Bryson Jim Reid Trophy , Derek McFadzen menrsquos handicap, Jeff Blundell ladies handicap, Margaret David.CHILDRENUnder school age, Alyth McFadzen P-, Grace McFadzen P-, Naomi Carroll Osbourne Trophy , Joshua Carroll. Walker Cup , Angus Smith.

title: 24-bags-rubbish-collected-gala-water-clean-up
story: VOLUNTEERS collected  bin-bags of rubbish along the north bank of the Gala water on Saturday.The Gala Waterways Group also cleared overgrown vegetation on the  metre stretch adjacent to Currie Road.As well as the  kilogrammes of rubbish, the  volunteers also removed a shopping trolley, a .-metres wide roll of plastic film, a hub-cap and two traffic cones.Gala Waterways chairperson Liz Jardine told us: "It was good to see such a good turnout of volunteers and the team worked overtime to clear an unexpected and challenging issue of flytipping."After all the rubbish removal and vegetation clear up we were ready for our tea, bacon rolls and cakes kindly provided by Adam Elder at Why Not Cafe on Channel Street."

title: peeblesshire-wedding-mansion-set-become-hotel
story: THE owners of a Peeblesshire mansion and wedding venue are hoping to turn it back to a hotel.The custodians of Hartree House, near Biggar, are hoping to offer year-round accommodation for guests, after a planning battle with the council two years ago left them able to host wedding parties, but not guests, in their mansion.The owners, Michael and Stephanie Goddard bought the th century house in , before spending around pound.m renovating the property and grounds.The Goddards were granted permission to turn the house into a wedding venue with marquees in July , but Scottish Borders Council imposed strict conditions on the use after receiving strong objections from neighbours.One condition, that the planning permission was only valid for two years, was removed on appeal but the condition that only two rooms can be rented out in the mansion at a time has remained in place.The most recent application, submitted by Lanark-based Burrel Design Studios on behalf of the Goddards, seeks to lt this condition and allow guests to stay in the mansions year-round.A supporting statement accompanying the application reads: ldquoThe effect of the councilrsquos ruling means that year-round self-catering accommodation may legitimately be offered in the lodge, the white house and penthouse, and the rights bestowed under the planning acts mean that year-round bed and breakfast accommodation may be offered for a maximum of two bedrooms within Hartree House.ldquoHowever, planning permission would be requiredthree or more bedrooms within Hartree House were occupied by guests.ldquoOver the last  years, the current owners of Hartree House have rescued the historic structure from being a building lsquoat riskrsquo to being a fully restored historic building incorporating some contemporary elements, which have served to reconcile former unsympathetic earlier additions and have made the building fit for occupation in the current age.ldquoRegrettably, the limitations imposed by the planning status of the property at Hartree have restricted the opportunity for the current owners to accommodate visitors who have wished to re-establish their connection with Hartree House.ldquoThe opportunity to offer accommodation in Hartree House to guests will add signicantly to the attraction of Hartree as a venue and will assist towards the upkeep of the house and grounds.A castle, known as Hartree Tower, was present on the site by at least the th century, but was demolished in the late th century by Colonel Alexander Dickson, who rebuilt the current Hartree House in its place.In , the property was passed to Elizabeth Dickson after her brother Archibald died unmarried.The house was used as a school during world war two, before being converted into a hotel in the post-war period.Hartree House was eventually neglected until the Goddards took over the property and converted it into a home in .

title: it-like-movie-says-lauder-cornet-chris
story: LAUDER tuned out in force on Saturday to mark the end of another successful week of celebrations.Locals and visitors alike lined the streets to be part of the traditional Common Riding Day.And it was an extra special day for Cornet Chris Purves and his Lass Zoe Bruce who had the honour of leading the mounted cavalcade.Cornet Purves told us: ldquoIt was like being in a movie.ldquoIt was so surreal.ldquoIt is so dficult to explain it all.ldquoEverybody told me in the run up to Common Riding Day I would be so nervous, that I wouldnrsquot be able to eat any breakfast.ldquoBut I think I was completely the opposite.ldquoThe support was fantastic.ldquoI just about managed to hold myself together when I saw everyone.ldquoI felt an immense sense of pride carrying the flag.ldquoEverybody tells you to take it all in because it goes so fast.ldquoIt really does, it feels like it was picking night yesterday.Cornet Purves said one of his favourite moments was the canter from the Waterinrsquo Stane.He added: ldquoIt is really dficult to pick just one moment.ldquoTurning around to see  horses following is incredible.ldquoI just couldnrsquot stop smiling throughout the whole day ndash even when there was no-one looking at me.ldquoI donrsquot know what I am going to do with myself now it is all over.ldquoI will be going to Coldstream Civic Week celebrations at the weekend, but it will be so strange not having to go to any other after that.It was also a memorable occasion for Chairman Ex-Cornet Ian Middlemiss.It was his final year in the role.He said: ldquoA huge thank you to all our committee and anyone who helped in any way to pull off another excellent Common Riding.ldquoIrsquom signing off now after a very enjoyable and busy five years as Chairman.ldquoThanks again to everyone for their support.

title: golden-gate-via-gala-textiles-student-heather
story: WHEN Heather Wilkie decided to study in Galashiels she never dreamt it would set her on a path to San Francisco.But the talented -year-old, who graduated in June from Heriot Watt Universityrsquos School of Textiles, has secured a lsquomind-blowingrsquo opportunity with one of the worldrsquos largest clothing companies, Old Navy.It is a journey that began just four years ago when Heather chose Heriot-Wattrsquos Design for Textiles course delivered at Netherdale.It was in her third-year, however, that Heatherrsquos big break arrived when she became the only student in Scotland to earn a three-month internship with Old Navy.She joined the companyrsquos graphics team at its impressive headquarters in San Francisco in June , where she worked on key projects, gaining rare insight into the hugely competitive industry.Heather explained: ldquoIt was an incredible experience, everyone was very friendly and looked out for me. What really surprised me, though, were the techniques Irsquod been taught at Heriot-Watt were the same as I was being shown at Old Navy.ldquoI had not expected that and it gave me a great confidence boost to know Irsquod been equipped with the skills and knowledge relevant to industry.Heatherrsquos knowledge and ability to learn impressed senior company figures and in May this year, she received a phone call out of the blue.ldquoThe phone rang one day and I was offered a full-time job in San Francisco, she recalled.ldquoI couldnrsquot believe it, I was absolutely blown away. My mum and dad were really pleased for me and are already looking forward to visiting on holiday!Born in the Philippines but raised in Glasgow, Heatherrsquos path to working in fashion and design began when she displayed a flair for art at Castlehead High School in Paisley.This would eventually lead her to choose Heriot-Watt in Galashiels, a decision she never regretted particularly after witnessing the close collaboration between the School and major global companies.She continued: ldquoChoosing the School of Textiles and Design has been an amazing experience for me and I would recommend to anyone who wants a career in this industry."The facilities are amazing and you get the opportunity to work independently on projects, which really appealed.Among the first to congratulate Heather on her new job is Professor Fiona Waldron, Head of School at the Heriot-Watt School of Textiles and Design.She said: ldquoHeatherrsquos story underlines the incredible opportunities that exist in this industry and our responsibility, as a university, is to help each and every one of our students achieve their goals.ldquoA huge number of our students go on to forge successful careers and we take great pride in teaching them skills and techniques that last a letime.Heather will begin her new role as a Print Design Assistant for the Menswear Print Team at the end of August.

title: exam-results-hotline-goes-live
story: HELP is at hand for all students following the opening of exam results.Thousands of senior pupils from across the Borders found out this weekthey had succeeded in their Highers and Nationals.Skills Development Scotland opened their exam results helpline to coincide with results being made available.Expert careers advisers will be on hand to discuss next steps with pupils and to provide more information to parents and carers who are keen to understand the choices available.The helpline is available from am to pm on both Tuesday and Wednesday, and then from am to pm from Thursday until next Wednesday.Deputy First Minister John Swinney met some of the advisers who will be standing by to provide dedicated support.He said: ldquoThis is an extremely signicant time but it is important to remember that this is the start of a journey, not the end."If your results are what you hoped for that is great news butyou miss out on the grades you were looking for, or do even better than expected, there is a huge iety of options available to you that the SDS careers advisers are on hand to talk through.The helpline -    - is free to call.Results information and advice is also available on Scotlandrsquos careers website My World of Work.James Russell, Skills Development Scotlandrsquos director of career information, said: ldquoIf your results arenrsquot what you expected donrsquot panic, you have lots of options.ldquoSkills Development Scotland is Scotlandrsquos career service and our experienced advisers are here to help you and your parents and carers with information on all the options and opportunities available to you.

title: timber-transport-cash-road-improvements
story: THREE rural roads in the Borders are to be improved after pound, of funding was secured from the Scottish Government.The A at Tweedsmuir, the B between Jedburgh and Newcastleton, and the C from Saughtree to Keilder will all be improved with the cash from the Strategic Timber Transport Fund.All three roads are used regularly by timber wagons.The funding, which totals pound, , will also go to a timber transport project officer who gives advice across the south of Scotland.Around pound. million has been allocated right across Scotland through the fund.Announcing the funding, Cabinet Secretary for the Rural Economy, Fergus Ewing, saidldquoScotlandrsquos pound billion forestry industry is going from strength to strength, producing millions of tonnes of high quality timber every year that will greatly benefit our rural economy.ldquoHowever, it is important that we do what we can to mitigate the impact on local communities of increased volumes of timber coming to market.ldquoThat is the key purpose of the Timber Transport Fund and it is encouraging to know that local authorities and forest owners continue to bring forward project ideas that will facilitate the sustainable transport of timber and ultimately benefit local communities and the environment.

title: gattonside-housing-development-given-green-light
story: A MELROSE-BASED developer has won its battle to build seven new homes in Gattonside.Rural Renaissance, which is the contracting arm of developer JS Crawfords, is planning on demolishing a small cottage along the B and building four one-storey and three two-storey homes on the site, which backs onto Montgomerie Terrace.A supporting statement, submitted on behalf of the developer by London-based planning consultancy Rapleys, reads: ldquoThe site rises up from the B to the north and is located within an existing established residential area. It is bounded to the west by Montgomerie Terrace.ldquoThe proposed new development will be accessed via a new access created off Montgomerie Terrace, with the two new houses towards the front of the site, which replace the existing ldquodoran pre-fab and former canoe shed, accessed off the B.ldquoThese proposed homes reflect high standards of design to ensure successful integration with the character of the local area, without damaging the design characteristics of the conservation area.ldquoThe materials, scale and height of the surrounding area have all been assessed to ensure the proposed development is in keeping with the existing housing.The plans attracted five objections relating to the height of the buildings in relation to nearby properties, and raised issues surrounding privacy and sunlight.However, at a meeting of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning and building standards committee on Monday August , planning officers urged councillors to approve the plans.In a written submission to the committee, planning officer Julie Hayward writes: ldquoThe main issue with the development is the potential impact of the dwellinghouses proposed on plots five and seven on the light, privacy and outlook of Orchard House to the east due to the position of the proposed houses and dfering ground levels.ldquoThe agent has submitted a drawing to show the relationship between the three houses and section drawings showing ground levels.ldquoIn terms of the impact of the proposed house on plot seven, the proposed house would have two bedroom windows in the east elevation at ground floor level and would be on slightly lower ground. Applying the guidelines in the approved supplementary planning guidance, there would be no signicant loss of light or privacy to Orchard House from this property.ldquoIn terms of the impact of the house on plot five on Orchard house, the garage would be positioned on the eastern side of the proposed house and the decking is shown on the western side beyond the rear wing.ldquoThere would be a window and door to the garage and a window to a WC in the rear elevation, which are not considered to be habitable rooms. There would be a large glazed area in the rear wing serving the living room.ldquoThe house is on signicantly higher ground than Orchard House.ldquoAgain, when applying the approved guidance there would be no direct overlooking and no loss of privacy to the habitable rooms of Orchard House.Kelso councillor Simon Mountford said he did not object to the proposals, but wanted to see a design change: ldquoWhat we have here those very boring roof shapes, although I appreciate modern roofs do not have chimneys or anything to break them up a little bit.ldquoIrsquom wonderingwe could ask the developer to break up the roof lines with some new designs.Tweeddale West councillor Eric Small told the committee: ldquoIrsquom quite happy with the way itrsquos sited in this location, so Irsquom going to go with the officers on this one. I think the design is perfect for where it.The majority of councillors agreed with councillor Mountford, and the application was approved with the condition that the developers must work with planning officers to redesign the roofs.

title: peebles-prepares-show-day
story: Peebles and the surrounding area is gearing up for the Peeblesshire Agricultural Societys Annual Show.This yearrsquos show is again being held at nether Horsburgh, near Cardrona, by kind permission of the Forestry Commission and Bill Renwick, and will take place on Saturday, August .As usual there will be an industrial tent, wool and shepherd sticks tent and a craft tent with stall holders selling local craft products.The show will feature over  dferent trade stands and an array of food stands showcasing the best of Scottish food.A food tent, supported by Quality Meat Scotland, will provide locally-sourced food and cookery demonstrations.Duck display team the Quack Commandos will entertain in the showrsquos main ring, alongside vintage tractor displays, private carriage driving and a young farmers obstacle course.Visitors will also be able to enjoy side saddle classes, pet shows, miniature donkeys and ferret races by the Scottish Ferret Club.Musical accompaniment to the dayrsquos events will be provided by Peebles Orchestra.Peeblesshire Agricultural Societyrsquos President, William Brown, said: ldquoWe have record cattle entries and very good entries in all other classes of stock.ldquoWe are very pleased to have MKM Galashiels on board as our main sponsor for this year and are very grateful to all the other businesses and iniduals that have sponsored the show.ldquoThis year the education tent is concentrating on poultry and egg production.ldquoWe are delighted to have Eggucation on board, and children will have the opportunity to handle chicks and grade eggs, along with all sorts of other fun activities.ldquoWe also have the Rare Breeds Survival Trust and the South of Scotland Golden Eagle Project with stands.Tickets are priced at pound for adults and pound for concessions. Admission is free for under-s.A free shuttle bus will run from Peebles and Innerleithen and fee parking will be available at the site.

title: delight-borders-pupils-make-grade
story: HEAD teachers from across the region have expressed their delight after exam results went live this week.More exams than ever before were taken in Borders schools this year.And the pass rates held high with  percent of all Ss gaining National  English, and  percent achieving National  maths.There was also a signicant increase of young people gaining qualications at SCQF Levels - across the region.Although breakdowns for inidual schools wont be publicly available for another few weeks, headteachers have praised the efforts of their students.Kevin Ryalls, head of Galashiels Academy, told us: "We would like to recognise the notable inidual achievements of many of our young people, including almost all of our S pupils who achieved at least five National Qualications."We also saw an increase in the number of young people achieving Higher passes in S."We would like to recognise the hard work and perseverance shown by our senior pupils, staff and parents and carers during the SQA exams."We congratulate our young people for their SQA examinations successes, as well as for the wide iety of achievements that have also been accomplished across the wider le of the school in the last session."The destinations of school leavers in the Borders also remains encouraging with . percent going into higher-, further-education, training or employment - an increase from last years . percent.Justin Sinclair, headteacher at Earlston High, said: "I am delighted with the performance of our pupils in this yearrsquos SQA examinations."We have had a record breaking year, particularly in S. I want to pay tribute to the hard work of all our pupils and staff."The number of young people attaining qualications from college is also exceptionally encouraging."Our record of continuous improvement and focus on excellence for all is evident in these superb results.Jedburgh Grammar also saw an increase in pass rates this year.Head teacher Susan Oliver told us: "In addition to outstanding inidual performances across qualication levels, a highlight of this yearrsquos SQA results is an increase in the number of Highers and Advanced Highers our young people are leaving school with."We would like to congratulate all of our pupils on their achievements and thank parents, staff, partner agencies and our community for their ongoing support.But results day is all about the pupils.Months of revision was put to the test during the spring.And for many the results will determine their next move.At Galashiels Academy, the pains of revision and exams were worthwhile for the vast majority of students.Cameron Beatt gained three Advanced Highers to go with last years haul of five Highers.,params: .pushThe former St Peters Primary pupil told us: "I have just had the news that I have passed my Advanced Highers in Maths, Chemistry and Business."I have a place at Strathclyde University where I will be studying for a degree in Accountancy and Finance."Fth year pupil Rosie McLeman was also delighted after achieving five As.She said: "I realise now that all the hard work I had put in was completely worth it and now I have the option to go to university and study medicine."I am so thankful for all the support from my friends, family and teachers whichit wasnt for them I wouldnt be able to achieve my goals."And S pupils Dylan Curran, Jordyn Kinsella and Emma Templeton were also overjoyed on Tuesday morning.Dylan said: "I spent a lot of time on revising for the subjects I chose this year and Irsquom glad that I got the results I hoped for."Emma added: "I am very pleased with my results, all my hard work has paid off!"The good news also reached Greece where Galashiels pupil Ellie Glendinning is on holiday.The teenager said: "I wasnrsquot very sureI would be able to receive my results as Im in Paxos."Luckily they came through and I was very happy with them and Irsquom quite proud of them as it shows my studying paid off."At Earlston the mood was just as good.Head Boy Finlay Dodds said: "I am delighted with my results."All the hard work paid off."I couldnrsquot have done it without the support from my teachers.Fellow sixth-year pupil Mia Presslie added: "I am extremely proud of myself and my results."The early start to revision was worth it!Councillor Carol Hamilton, who is responsible for education, spent Tuesday morning at Eyemouth High School with pupils as they received their results by text and post.She said: ldquoFor some, the results they receive today will be vital in getting a place at university, but for many others they will just be one small step towards a job, a Modern Apprenticeship, further education or simply being able to take their preferred subjects and qualications in their next school year.ldquoWhatever their situation, Irsquod like to commend the young people of the Scottish Borders on their results and hard work this year, and thank their teachers, parents and carers for their support."

title: horse-charity-39-s-last-gasp-bid-clear-final-fundraising-hurdle
story: A HORSE-RIDING charity which has supported hundreds of disadvantaged youngsters is facing a race against time.Stable Le has been providing equine assisted learning ever since growing out of the Gala Youth project more than a decade ago.But central to its courses and therapies at its Ashkirk base is an indoor riding school.And much of Stable Les income is also generated from commercial clients who use the facility.Mags Powell from Stable Le told us: "Our indoor riding school is over  years old and is in need of an essential renovation."The structure needs to be strengthened to make it wind and water tight, the roof and windows leak and urgently need to be replaced."The building is currently dark, damp and cold."We are very worried thatthe building is left to deteriorate further we will not be able to support the  or so vulnerable young people referred to us each year."Over the past few months staff at the charity have been developing plans to secure and future-proof the indoor school.Having already held fundraising events and securing pound, from Scottish Borders Councils Localities Bid Fund, they are now attempting to find the final pound, required through an online Crowdfunding appeal.But time is running out.Mags added: "The Crowdfunding campaign will only be fundedthe final pound, is pledged before August ."Any amount of pledge would be very welcome and there are some lovely rewards generously donated from ious companies and iniduals up for grabs."Despite the major fundraising campaign and worries over the future of its indoor riding school, Stable Le has continued to support support young people and their families who are experiencing personal challenges.Their equine assisted learning allows each student to discover a sense of self, build resilience and learn transferable le skills while working with horses.An ongoing Out of the Woods project, which will run until next March gives young people the opportunity to gain an SQA Level  qualication in Horse Care.The first class of eight students started the course in January with all of them making the grade.Stable Le team leader Cindy Davie said: ldquoThe NPA Level  in Horse Care was developed for learners who found a classroom environment a barrier to learning."All of our students attended for a full day, completing work on the yard, riding lessons, and a small amount of cabin based activities."As with every new venture there are teething problems, however our students engaged and worked their way through them."Feedback from families and referring agencies commented on the growth of confidence of the young people."They developed from a very quiet group of iniduals in to a whole bundle of fun and laughter! All eight learners completed the units, and had a pathway for future learning in place."A second group of students is currently working towards the qualication, with a further class set to start later this month.Cindy added: "Staff are currently undergoing training to be able to deliver Youth Achievement Awards, which we hope to be able to ersy and offer through our Environmental and Leskills groups, as well as the Horse Care."We would like to say a huge thank you to Borders College for their support, and external verication, and we look forward to growing together in the future.To support Stable Les appeal indoor riding school appeal go to www.crowdfunder stable-le-save-our-school

title: isabelle-39-s-design-collecting-accolades
story: A PEEBLES pupil has designs on donations at Tweeddale Museum and Gallery.Fth year pupil Isabelle Elsmore was tasked with making something on the theme of the The Great Outdoors for her National  Design and Manufacture portfolio.The team at Tweeddale Museum were in need of a new donation box and they had already approached Peebles High Schools technology department to seepupils would be interested in creating one.When Isabelle approached staff with her design brief they were delighted with her plans.Isabellersquos design incorporates branches, twigs and leaves, which not only celebrate The Great Outdoors, but also complement the current exhibition, Intertwined, in which textile artists Rose Campbell and Alison King take inspiration from the beautul forests surrounding Peebles.Assistant curator Phoebe Stewart: "Itrsquos wonderful for Tweeddale museum to work collaboratively with Peebles High School - and what a wonderful outcome for all involved.ldquoAs a charity, Live Borders aims to invest in the local community, and we are so pleased with our new box from the very talented Isabelle!ldquoWe would like to thank staff at Peebles High School for their co-operation and we wish Isabelle all the best in her future career and plans."Without doubt she is very creative and talented, and who knows, maybe one day she will exhibit more of her work at Tweeddale Museum.

title: entries-open-borders-ms-fun-run
story: IT has become one of the most recognisable races in the Borders.And yet again the orange-topped athletes will be raising vital funds for the Multiple Sclerosis Society Borders group.On Sunday, September  the th Borders MS Fun Run will get underway at Priorwood House in Melrose.And yet again the km run will be sponsored by JS Crawford developers.Judy Eglington from the MS Society Borders group told us: "The fun run will once again raise money so that we can provide very beneficial therapies for people affected by MS in the Borders."These therapies help people affected by MS to retain some independence and sense of well being."Among the services provided for MS sufferers are hydrotherapy, power-plate sessions, yoga classes, physiotherapy, remedial massage, aromatherapy and reflexology.But it all comes at a cost.Judy added: "Our hydrotherapy is particularly beneficial to people with MS who have very limited mobility as they are able to walk-in the pool something they are unable to do on dry land."The annual cost of the therapies are approximately pound, so the group is delighted with the huge amount of support that they receive from people in the Borders."The group also provides emotional and practical support including accessing grants."The Borders MS Fun Run is open to everyone and is both wheelchair and dog friendly.This years runners will come under starters orders at noon on September .Further information and entry forms are available from www.jscrawfordAnyone affected by MS can get further information on MS Society Borders group at borders@mssociety.org.uk

title: 50-green-homes-built-borders-next-year
story: UP to  energy efficient, affordable homes are set to be built in the Borders next year.Eildon Housing association has announced it will create the new houses set across four communities.And Innerleithen and Broughton are on the list along with Westruther and Denholm.A spokesperson for the social landlord said: "Warmer, cheaper, more affordable homes is something we all want, and this could be a reality as Eildon Housing look at future house building and its impact on the environment."The need for affordable housing in the Borders has hit an all-time high, with recent figures showing, on average,  people bidding for every home that becomes available."To meet this need it is important to be able to build a house quicker and make it cheaper to heat and therefore eradicate fuel poverty especially in rural parts of the Borders reducing our use of fossil fuels."Working in partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Construction Scotland Innovation Centre and Glasgow School of Art, the new developments will be part of a study to compare construction costs, time to build, living quality, and whether the homes are financially viable to build.The spokesperson added: "The developments at Westruther, Broughton, Denholm and Innerleithen will see up to  new green homes built and will test dferent building methods from passivhaus, energiesprong, volumetric and the traditional build wersquore all used to."Potential new tenants will be heavily involved in the study for a period of time when they move in, as the results will be used to determine not only the future building programme for Eildon, but also lead the way for how Scottish homes are built and lived in, in the future."

title: end-road-peebles-british-legion
story: VETERANS in Peebles have confirmed that the towns branch of the Royal British Legion is to close later this year.For more than nine decades the armed forces charity has helped thousands of former service personnel in and around Peebles.And its members have played a key part in maintaining the regions War Memorials as well as raising vital funds.But with membership numbers dropping each year - currently standing at  - and dficulties in recruiting post holders, time has been called on the local organisation.Mike Stark, who has been at the forefront of keeping the Peebles branch operating, told us: "We have an ageing membership - many of us are in our s and s - and finding people to take on committee posts such as chair or treasurer has been a struggle."It is with a great deal of sadness that this decision has been made."The Royal British Legion was founded in  to help survivors of World War One as well as their families.A sale of poppies each year has allowed that work to continue for servicemen and and women ing from more modern wars, with around , branches still operating across the country.The Peebles branch of the Royal British Legion Scotland will officially close on October .Prior to the winding up, a laying of the branchs Colours ceremony will take place at Peebles Parish Church on Sunday, September .The flags will be permanently displayed within the Church next to commemorative tablets for fallen soldiers of World War I.Ahead of the service, retiring officials hope to locate the exact date that the Peebles branch was formed for inscription on a plaque.Mr Stark explained: "We believe the branch was formed in  but we dont have records of the exact date."If anyone has any information on the forming of the branch we would like to hear from them."

title: musical-masterpieces-gala-39-s-best-kept-secret
story: ONE of the Scottish music scenes best kept secrets has emerged yet again from its Galashiels laboratory.Electron Mass has just released its fourth quartet of atmospheric mini-masterpieces.And while they wont be troubling the commercial airwaves or the even more commercial charts, yet again this duo and their friends have made their mark.Songwriters Sorensen Small and Brendan McAndrew use Electron Mass as an outlet for their unusual collaborations about science, nature and the cosmos.In their previous carnation, Small and McAndrew produced a stunning album as the Stone Ghost Collective.While they have moved the focus of their microscope away from unrequited love, they have managed to maintain something beautul with compositions about space, the Earth, the human mind and death.As Electron Mass, they released three wonderful EPs - Earthlight, Luminous and Selene - during .Last week they added to their canon for the curious with four more instantly appealing, yet erse, songs, neatly packed together as The Dopamine Girl EP.Each compelling composition while dferent from the next, encompasses beautul orchestration and haunting harmonies.And while it may take a degree or two to decipher the cryptic cantations, as with the previous EPs, The Dopamine Girl is a press repeat type of listen.Title track Dopamine Girl is, in their words, a short and sweet alternative-pop song... We knew it would last forever, but forever had its day.The Twin Peaks-inspired Love Dilation is as dark as it is atmospheric.But it is perhaps the utterly engrossing simplicity of Imprints that makes it so special. While McAndrew has the harmonic range, Smalls almost monotoned meanderings, accompanied by the backing vocals of Grant Pringle and Cameron Jack, creates the rawest of emotions.Concluding the new EP is the orchestral art-song, A Theory of Everything. Built around a single, beautully menacing chord, which apparently symbolises the background radiation in our universe, the finale discusses the search for discovering a unying theory of everything.To quote Small from Imprints, As you travel through space, you are displaced, imagining time. You exist like a plant, you bloom and you grow, then wither and die. But the one card you play, genetically, is always an ace. For the imprints you leave, have changed the fabric of time and space.If there is any justice in the supersonic space-age future, Electron Masss four EPs will hopefully have changed the fabric of music down here on Earth.

title: storms-expected-batter-borders-weekend
story: A WEATHER warning and a flooding alert have been issued for the Scottish Borders today.The storms are also expected to continue throughout the weekend.Heavy rain has already left many roads with deep standing water.And water courses throughout the region are starting to rise.A spokesman for the Scottish Environmental Protection Agencysaid: "A band of heavy, persistent rain will push northward from the early morning across southern and central Scotland on Friday."This may lead to localised flooding from surface water and smaller rivers."Built up areas and the transport network are at greater risk where possible impacts could include: flooding of low-lying land, roads, properties and disruption to travel particularly around the Friday morning rush hour."Further heavy and thundery showers are likely to develop across the area later on Friday and Saturday."A yellow warning for rain is in force today from the Met Office.A rain and thunder warning is in place for tomorrow while a thunder warning has been issued for Sunday.

title: hearing-held-barrel-law-wind-farm-plans
story: A HEARING has been held by Scottish Government officials to discuss the proposed new wind farm at Barrel Law, near Hawick.In September, plans for an poundm wind farm were rejected by Scottish Borders councillors.The proposal would have seen seven turbines, of up to m in height, erected on land to the north-west of Roberton, near Hawick.The company behind the plans, Germany-based ABO Wind, then submitted an appeal to the Scottish Governmentrsquos planning and environmental appeals ision .As part of that appeal process, the DPEArsquos appointed reporter Elspeth Cook held a hearing at Forman Hall, Roberton.However, the hearing was simply to clary and define legal terms and certain technical standards in order to help inform Ms Cookrsquos decision.For example, one point of contention between Scottish Borders Council and ABO Wind is whether or not the combined appearance of Barrel Law and the existing wind turbines at Langhope Rig will create a lsquolandscape with wind turbinesrsquo or a lsquowind turbine landscapersquo, as per the legally-defined definitions.The councilrsquos position is that a distance of between -km is required in order to maintain the current landscape type in the valley, but ABO Wind suggest the turbines should be less than km apart, as they state that spreading out the two turbine sites would actually make the landscape look more saturated as the wind turbines would effectively cover a larger area.Furthermore, they state that a greater distance between the two developments would push the Barrel Law turbines outside of the topography which makes wind farms viable in this area.Appearing as part of ABO Windrsquos  of representatives, land and development consultant James Welsh told the reporter: ldquoIn our opinion we preserve the distinct identity of the two groups.ldquoThere are examples of wind farms being approved with similar distances between them but still being accepted as being clearly separate wind farms.ldquoTo insist on a greater separation would increase the effect of a cumulative effect between them.Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning consultant, Dr Guy Wimble, said: ldquoI donrsquot dispute that they are identiable as separate elements, my issue is the effect of the wind farms on the landscape, and recognising that they are two dferent wind farms not one development.ldquoThe proximity of them makes this appear more of a wind farm landscape rather a landscape with wind farms.ldquoWhile I accept that separating the developments would make the wind farms seem more spaced out, by putting them closer yoursquod increase density.John Campbel QC, appearing on behalf of a group of objectors called Barrel Law Action Group, said: ldquoIf you pull the wind farms apart then clearly you increase the area of cumulative effect.ldquoIf you pull them together, yoursquore going to increase the cumulative effect just by sheer numbers, and you lose the ability to discern the two as distinct entities.Melrose and Leaderdale councillor Tom Miers, appearing in his capacity as Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for planning and environment, told the hearing: ldquoIt seems to me that the guidance allows for developments in this area but doesnrsquot necessarily promote it.ldquoNo one is disputing that the two wind farms would be separate, wersquore working to find out what degree of separation would be appropriate.Mr Welsh responded: ldquoIf you increase to a km distance it will push all m turbines outwith the area that has been identied as having the appropriate topography for this type of development.Ms Cook also sought clarication on certain technical points, mostly surrounding tables and figures contained within ious reports submitted by the appellant and the local authority.

title: art-thou-shakespeare-cyclists
story: BORDERS venues are to welcome the worldrsquos only cycling Shakespeare company this Autumn.Each summer the HandleBards acting troupes cycle riotously funny versions of Shakespearersquos classics across the UK.And after a quick stop off at the Edinburgh Fringe, they are moving onto the Borders and the rest of Scotland.This year, the HandleBards present The Tempest and Much Ado About Nothing to two Border towns.Each troupe is made up of four actors who cycle up to  miles a day, then set up their show, perform it, take down the set, then collapse in a heap!As the troupes have to take it slow, they get a sense of each area they perform in, saying lsquowe meet lovely localsrsquo and that they have even been known to lsquohunt down some wild swimming locations in the Bordersrsquo.Firstly, the all-female troupe will bring their lsquocompletely barmyrsquo The Tempest to Kailzie Gardens in Peebles.Then the all-male troupe will bring their witty Much Ado About Nothing to Bowhill House, outside Selkirk.The HandleBards take on the Tempest imagines Prospero as a faded vaudevillian magician, whose tricks have somewhat lost their lustre.Combining romance, music, real magic tricks and four tour-de-force performances, this show is one for the young, the old and everyone in between.While the troupersquos version of Much Ado About Nothing includes music, dancing and a lot of silly characters.Audiences are warned to look out for the dastardly Don Jon and look out for the HandleBards plundering your picnic.After forming in , the touring Shakespeare group have gone on to perform to over , people in castles, gardens, museums and public amphitheatres.Jack, Producer for The HandleBards, told us: ldquoWersquove performed in the Borders every year since the HandleBards started in , and we always receive a warm welcome.ldquoWe are excited to perform at some breathtakingly beautul venues - the majestic Bowhill House, and the bucolic Kailzie Gardens.ldquoWe love performing in the Borders area, itrsquos really a milestone for us, moving from our extensive English and Welsh touring, then breaking into beautul Scotland.ldquoIt usually means wersquove got about a third of the tours left, which is welcome news for our heroic troupes, who will each have cycled  miles already!Since they began, the group has cycled over , miles across the whole of the UK.And this autumn they will surpass the ,-mile mark with both productions.They are proud to be the only theatre company to combine sustainability and Shakespeare, while leading the way on achieving accessible and affordable theatre for all ages.Jack added: ldquoWhile the biggest theatre festival in the world takes place in Edinburgh, wersquore proud to bring theatre to venues all over Scotland and the Borders.ldquoOur all-female The Tempest is completely barmy, and totally magical.ldquoAnd our all-male Much Ado About Nothing is a witty, fast paced romp through one of Shakespearersquos best-loved plays.ldquoOur Scottish audiences are always brilliant, and wersquod love to get as many people along to this Summerrsquos shows as possible.Much Ado About Nothing takes place at Bowhill House on September  at .pm.The Tempest will take place at Kailzie Gardens on August  at .pm.Tickets for both shows can be found at https:www.handlebards tickets

title: boy-found-safe-boarding-bus-distressed-state-wearing-pyjamas
story: A boy seen boarding a bus in slippers and a dressing gown in a ldquodistressed state on Saturday night has been found after a large-scale search, police said. Police, who called it a ldquoparticularly unusual case, said on Sunday morning they had spoken with the family of the child, believed to be  or , and that he was safe. title: thank-lucky-stars-dean-friedman-39-s-coming-st-boswells
story: HE was one of the voices of the s - and you can thank your Lucky Stars hes coming to St Boswells Village Hall.New Jersey-born Dean Friedman has retained a cult following since his stream of hits in the late s.This week his epic -date tour of the UK and Ireland takes him to the Edinburgh Festival for three nights before arriving at St Boswells Live on Saturday.Last year marked Deanrsquos th anniversary in the music industry, where he celebrated with a sold-out UK tour and the re-release of his digitally remastered,  ground breaking album Well, Well, said the Rocking Chair.On this latest tour Friedman will be performing solo, on guitar and keyboards, featuring songs from throughout his four decade recording career, including his classic hits Lucky Stars, Lydia, McDonaldrsquos Girl, Ariel and Woman of Mine, as well as selections from his last studio album,  Songs.Doors open for Dean Friedman at St Boswells Live at .pm on Saturday.Tickets, priced at pound and pound for concessions, are available at the Old Post Office in St Boswells or online at Music Glue.And IF any remain they will be available to purchase on the door on the evening of the concert.

title: paxton-house-opens-39-s-doors-trust-members
story: ONE of the Bordersrsquo most historic homes can now be enjoyed for free by members of the National Trust for Scotland.National Trust for Scotland is a charity that protects Scotlandrsquos national and natural treasures.Now members can enjoy the exquisite Paxton House in Berwickshire free of charge.Conservation charity members can explore all that the Palladian mansion has to offer, including its nationally signicant collection of Chippendale and Trotter furniture and masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland.And children can enjoy the Teddy Trail that runs throughout the house.Paxton House is owned and managed by Paxton Trust, a charitable trust that also manages the -acre estate set on the banks of the Tweed.In the extensive grounds there are gardens, woodland, an adventure playpark and even a den building area, plus the Stables Tearoom and the Regency Gt shop.Ian Marrian, Chairman of the Paxton Trust, said: ldquoThe team at Paxton House are excited to share this Borders treasure with members of the National Trust for Scotland and we look forward to welcoming them soon.National Trust for Scotland members can now show their valid membership upon arrival for free access to Paxton House.Mark Bishop, Director of Customer  Cause for the National Trust for Scotland, said: ldquoWersquore so pleased that Paxton House is throwing its doors open to our members who will love its beautul collections and interiors, and gorgeous grounds.ldquoThis gives our members even more reason to explore the Borders and the beautul places we protect here, for the love of Scotland.Also protected by the National Trust for Scotland are St Abbrsquos Head National Nature Reserve, Robert Smailrsquos Printing Works in Innerleithen, and Harmony Gardens in Melrose.

title: accomplished-borders-musicians-bring-international-flair-bowden
story: Award-winning Borders musicians will get toes tapping with a fusion performance in Bowden this weekend.Multi-talented instrumentalists, Paul Chamberlain and Michael Haywood, will be delighting audiences at a concert in Bowden Village Hall on Friday.With a fresh take on world music Chamberlain  Haywood take their instruments on an international tour of the sultry sounds of the Tango, the rhythmic drive of the Balkans, along with rip-roaring tunes from Russia and Scotland.A promoter for the band commented: ldquoVirtuoso playing, and fresh musical ideas, Paul and Michael explore the potential of their instruments in a way that is exciting and engaging.ldquoThey take the strength of each instrumentrsquos traditions and blend them into their own unique brand of fusion music. The result is a vibrant, intriguing and occasionally explosive mix of music that crosses cultural boundaries.Both musicians grew up in the Borders, and a common interest in traditional music brought them together.Whilst still maintaining these traditional roots, the combination of Michaels jazz influenced style, and Pauls classical training come together to create a dynamic performance bursting with energy.Michael gained an honors degree in folk and traditional music from Newcastle University with a major in wind instruments.Since graduating, he has appeared at leading venues such as the Glasgow Royal Concert Hall, Sage Gateshead, The Barbican, and he has even played on BBC Radio Scotland.Now, Michael teaches music locally at Earlston High School.Paul was one of the first classical accordionists to graduate from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland in Glasgow, where he graduated with a Master of Music Performance with Distinction.Whilst studying there he was awarded the acclaimed Governors Recital Prize for Keyboard and was also one of the keyboard section finalists in the  Royal Overseas League competition.Paul has made appearances at international music festivals such as Baltica Harmonica in St. Petersburg ndash Russia, Sata-Haumlme Soi Accordion festival in Ikaalinen ndash Finland, and the world-famous Edinburgh Fringe Festival.And he completed a major national tour of concerts in July  to coincide with his second CD release lsquoAccordion Sensationsrsquo.The concert takes place at Bowden Village Hall on Friday, August  at .pm.Tickets are pound for Adults and under rsquos go free.Chamberlain  Haywood will also be performing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival on Sunday August .More information is available at www.chamberlain-haywood

title: harland-wolff-auld-hands-leave-palm-prints-concrete
story: Former workers at a closure-threatened Belfast shipyard have ed to leave their handprints for posterity as the battle to save the business goes on.Queues of retired ship builders, known as ldquoauld hands, lined up at Harland and Wolff on Sunday to place their palms in trays of setting concrete.----Famed for building the Titanic, the shipyard went into administration last week after its troubled Norwegian parent company, Dolphin Drilling, failed to find a buyer.Workers who have occupied the site round the clock for almost two weeks as part of a high-profile campaign to save the yard organised the handprint event on Sunday.Such was the turnout that extra concrete had to be poured to accommodate all those wishing to leave their mark. Old and young took part, with some former ship builders aged in their s joining members of the current workforce in the lines.The gathering of the generations of workers came as administrators continue to explore a number of potential bids for the company.--vw,vw,px, px"Handprints were left by former shipyard workers in wet cement --BDO Northern Ireland has agreed to a ldquotemporary unpaid lay-off of the workforce until Friday to enable those commercial opportunities to be explored.While the workers are no longer getting paid, the move means their contracts of employment remain unbroken.Ex-foreman Samuel Tumelty, who worked for the shipyard for  years, was helped from his wheelchair to place his palm in the concrete.ldquoIt would be hard to seeit does go, my heart is still in this company, he said.ldquoI hope it can be saved. The men need their livelihoods and to throw them out in the street is unbelievable. The amount of ships they built and the quality of the ships, they were top notch. It would be very sad to see it going.--vw,vw,px, px"Extra concrete had to be poured to accommodate all those wishing to take part --Former steelworker Herbie Stewart from Lisburn, who lost a finger in his time working in the yard, said he felt it was important to come down.ldquoItrsquos a landmark, at the end of the day itrsquos something thatrsquos been here for years and years, he said.ldquoMost of my family worked here years ago and I would have been the last.Jackie Hosick, from west Belfast, spent most of his working le in the yard.ldquoIrsquom here just to support the rest of the fellas that work in the yard here and hope they do well out of this, he said.ldquoThe men who worked down here were all characters, it was brilliant.ldquoItrsquos terrible ndash a lot of the auld fellas would turn in their grave to see whatrsquos happening.--vw,vw,px, px"Former shipyard workers Jackie Hosick and Samuel Tumelty --Steelworker and GMU shop steward Barry Reid said he was surprised by the turnout.ldquoThis is the auld hands ndash a lot of the communities in Belfast had a connection with Harland and Wolff so this is our way of saying to the community come down and put your handprint down for posterity, he said.Mr Reid saidthe yard ultimately closed he hoped the concrete casts would end up in a museum.ldquoIf we do stay open and we do get a buyer we are hoping that the buyer will let us put them down around the entrance, he added.ldquoAt the end of the day this is part of the history of the company.Susan Fitzgerald from the Unite union said she remained optimistic that a solution could be found. She said some of the potential offers for the company were ldquocredible.ldquoWe have had an incredible day where hundreds of auld hands and their families have turned out to have their hands cast in concrete to show the role they have played and more fundamentally the role they are playing to preserve this yard into the future, she said.ldquoThey have turned out today to show full support and solidarity for the workers who have taken a stand to defend jobs and defend the shipyard.ldquoWe are hopeful of getting a resolution here that does save the jobs, that does save the yard.ldquoTherersquos a lot going on every day, virtually around the clock, there is work being done to try to create a situation where we can be victorious and save the jobs and the future of the shipyard.ldquoSo long as we stand here and we declare that we are willing to fight and defend this place to the end, therersquos hope..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Harland and Wolff  uauld hands u leave palm prints in concrete

title: green-mp-calls-emergency-cabinet-women-stop-no-deal-brexit
story: Green Party MP Caroline Lucas is calling on leading women politicians to come together to prevent a ldquocrash-out Brexit.Ms Lucas has written to  other female politicians opposed to a no-deal break with the EU inviting them to form an ldquoemergency cabinet.She said the aim would be to secure a Commons vote of no-confidence in Boris Johnson followed by the formation of a government of national unity.Among the women she his invited to join her are Labourrsquos shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry, Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson and Scotlandrsquos First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.Writing in , Ms Lucas said: ldquoWe need an rsquoemergency cabinetrsquo ndash not to fight a Brexit war but to work for reconciliation. And I believe this should be a cabinet of women.ldquoWhy women  Because I believe women have shown they can bring a dferent perspective to crises, are able to reach out to those they disagree with and cooperate to find solutions.ldquoA government of national unity must do exactly that ndash unite parties. And I believe that a cross-party cabinet of women has the potential to do exactly that.The other MPs contacted by Ms Lucas are Tory former cabinet minister Justine Greening, senior Labour backbencher Yvette Cooper, the SNPrsquos Kirsty Blackman, Liz Saville Roberts of Plaid Cymru, Change UKrsquos Anna Soubry and the independents Heidi Allen and Lady Sylvia Hermon..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Green MP calls for an  uemergency cabinet u of women to stop no-deal Brexit

title: letter islay in darkness
story: We are concerned that the installation of new streetlights, mounted on metal lamp-posts, could detract from the appearance of some roads in Port Charlotte, which is a designated conservation area. The new lights would replace wall-mounted lights and could, residents fear, make a signicant impact on the character of the area.A number of residents have been in contact about this matter as they fear that the introduction of these lights, which are really more suited to an urban setting, are inappropriate to their village.I think it is incumbent on the council to show some regard to their concerns as local people are, rightly, proud of their architectural heritage and do not want to see it compromised by the insensitive implementation of a policy which is not appropriate for their community.I would urge them to look again at this issue.Donald Cameron MSP,

title: a little light chamber music
story: The programme was based on th century compositions and featured works of three of the great romantic composers. The opening piece by Saint-Saëns was the perfect choice for the more intimate style of the smaller-scale orchestra. The central work was Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto in which the orchestra’s Director, Benjamin Marquise Gilmore, played the solo part and gave a stunning performance.At the end of the first movement, the audience were treated to an outstanding display of professionalism from the orchestra, when one of the strings on the soloist’s violin snapped, but then watched the smoothest of transitions as the player at the first desk immediately handed the soloist her own violin and the music continued uninterrupted while another player repaired the broken string.The concert finished with Beethoven’s nd Symphony and it was especially good to hear the use of natural trumpets and horns in this early but most attractive work. Also singled out for praise was the woodwind section and knitting all the performances together was the New Zealand conductor, Holly Mathieson. A most enjoyable evening.                                                                                                                          David McEwanHolly Mathieson conducts the Scottish Chamber Orchestra. story: Sir,I wish to thank all the people of Campbeltown and especially the members of Yes Kintyre for the wonderful hospitality they gave us independence marchers on Saturday. I#ve been on many a demonstration in my time and this was one of the best.Rolling off the ferry on the Friday evening we were welcomed by a guard-of-honour standing along the pier waving saltires.The townsfolk turned out in droves to welcome us, waving saltires from windows and even stringing saltire bunting across the street at fourth-storey level. I had the romantic impression that the good folk of Campbeltown had been following the ious pro-independence rallies as they worked their way around the geography of Scotland and had just been waiting for their own town#s turn!The sun stayed out for us right until pm. Then the rain suddenly came down and we took down our Pensioners for Independence stall.  That evening Yes Kintyre put on a special party for us all with local musicians in the Argyll Arms Hotel.On Sunday some of us stayed on and explored your beautul peninsula. As the ferry pulled away that evening members of Yes Kintyre stood along the harbour wall holding up saltires to bid us farewell.Thank you all again for a memorable experience.Yours,Mary McCabe,Glasgow.Sir,It was my great privilege to attend yet another Open at Royal Portrush and to witness  year-old Oban golfer Robert MacIntyre finish tied sixth in his very first Major Championship.It was a wonderful performance, and confirmation, of the talent and the temperament we, the journalists, felt sure that he had.  He is now a Euro millionaire, but he remains an open, helpful and cheerful lad with both feet firmly planted on the ground, thanks to a great family and a strong desire to remain in his home town.I was at Glencruitten for the first time in June and soon discovered why Robert wants to go back there on a regular basis after weeks on tour.  It#s a terric club, no airs and graces.  They are very proud of Robert, and rightly so, but I very much doubtthey would allow him to lose his down-to-earth approach to international recognition.Yours,Jock MacVicar, Southend-born Scottishgolf correspondent and long-time Dunaverty member. Sir,Through the columns of your newspaper, may I express my grateful thanks to all the businesses, organisations, and iniduals, who donated to our fundraising, allowing the dancers to compete in the United States Highland Dancing Championships held recently in Las Vegas.We had a very successful trip, placing in both the Highland and choreography events. It’s installed in the dancers they are there to represent Campbeltown and the Dance School rather than any inidual, and hearing the town name announced at the presentation of trophies to our four trophy winners was a very proud moment indeed. The dancers fought every inch of the way to put our small town on the map.Our thanks once again to the following: MACC, Tangy Wind Farm, West Kintyre Wind Farm, Killieguer Caravan Park, DM Fabrication, Glenside Tractors, Howdens, Kintyre Youth Fund, McFadyens Contractors, Tesco Bags of Help, Jim Martin Supplies, Southend Parish Church, Peter McKerral  Son, C’town Co-Op, C’town Running Club, C’town Rotary Club, C’town Firemans Club, C’town Motor Co, C’town Rotary Club, C’town Loyal, C’town Common Good Fund, C’town Inner Wheel, C’town Community Council, Paul Grumoli, Mr and Mrs Brown, Mr and Mrs Russell, and Laura and Jake, Tesco Staff.Yours,James McCorkindale,McCorkindale School of Dancing.Sir,On Monday evening, July , five sacks of tin cans had been placed in the clear glass bin in Tesco#s car park. title: campbeltown rallies to independence march
story: The independence march through Campbeltown on Saturday was a huge success and put a real zest for le back into the town which has been too long forgotten.That was the view of organiser Manny Singh who despite his apparent sacking from the All Under One Banner organisation was very much still in charge at the Campbeltown march.Afterwards he said: #It was a huge success for Campbeltown and the biggest demonstration for decades. There was a lot of spirit and a feeling that a number of towns in Scotland which have been forgotten, like Campbeltown, will not be left behind after independence.#He put the turnout at more than , and added: #The fact that the march extended theof Longrow gives a fair indication of the numbers who were there.He also told the Courier this week that he remained the #legal indentity# of the All Under One Banner group, despite a bitter public row among the hierarchy which looks like splitting the group in two.It was the biggest rally held in the town in recent years with marchers coming from as far afield as Aberdeen and Alloa and as well as Oban, Glasgow and Islay, with many travelling on the weekend ferry from Ardrossan.#It really exceeded expectations and made a big splash in the town, Ron Wilson of Yes Kintyre told The National.#There was a real buzz as people came early and most of the hotels were booked up. The pubs and cafes were busy so it was good for local businesses. Campbeltown is a Yes town and it was brilliant to have all these people come here. Local people were coming off the pavements and joining the procession so it created a good, positive vibe.Pro-Unionists opponents held their own counter demonstation. However, the march went off without any incident and there were no arrests, with only one warning which was drug related.A spit of rain earlier in the day failed to develop into poor weather as the marchers would round the town to hear speakers and listen to musicians at the rally at Kinloch Green.Mr Wilson said he was particuarly pleased at the turnout as there had been some confusion over whether the march would go ahead due to internal sions within the hierachcy of All Under One Banner, which has organised independence marches across the country.Following Mr Singh#s sacking, founder Neil Mackay resigned from his position on its national executive pending an internal investigation.Pro-UK Unionist group A Force For Good met the march on the shore front and say they filmed and counted the marchers, as they have at previous events, and afterwards claimed the turnout was just .Director, Alistair McConnachie, said: #All Under One Banner is basically the marching wing of the SNP. title: thought for the week week 31
story: Imagine. Imagine a world where no one was hungry, a world where no one was homeless, a world where the most powerless were given a voice.Imagine. title: letter one of scotlands best kept secrets
story: We are fortunate in Scotland to have a way out of such dficulties in the form of a Debt Arrangement Scheme , which is one of Scotland’s best-kept secrets.  It’s available from charitable organisations such as StepChange and from commercial debt advisers such as TC Debt Solutions, too.  It is a Scottish Government scheme that is legally binding and prevents creditors from taking further action against people who owe money.Set up back in  by the Scottish Government, the scheme allows people to freeze interest and charges on their debts and pay their debts off interest-free over a longer period of time.  This brings payments down to levels that people can afford and gives people the chance to get their lives back on track.  Interest and charges are simply written off.Apart from reducing debt, one of the best things about the DAS scheme is that it protects people from their creditors but is not a form of insolvency: people get to pay back their debt in an affordable way.  Lenders like the scheme because they know they will eventually get their money back – and borrowers like it because they don’t have to pay interest charges and they get longer to pay their debts off.  It’s a case of everyone wins.There’s plenty of information about the Debt Arrangement Scheme online at  www.aib.gov.uk debt-arrangement-scheme.  Thousands of people have used the scheme, but so many more could get this help – whether through financial charities or commercial organisations.Richard Gardiner,
